The text discusses the study of entanglement in quantum multipartite systems, focusing on the essential features and dynamical behavior of entanglement under the influence of decoherence. It presents findings on the entanglement distribution among two qubits embedded in two independent amplitude damping reservoirs, showing that entanglement can be stably distributed across all subsystems, regardless of the markovian approximate result or decoherenceless double j-c model result. This result is significant to the study of the physical nature of entanglement under decoherence and implies an active way to protect entanglement from decoherence by modifying the properties of reservoirs. The need for efficient use of wireless spectrum in cognitive radio networks has led to the analysis of cognitive radio systems. One possible scheme for the operation of the cognitive radio network is to allow secondary users to transmit concurrently on the same frequency band with primary users as long as the resulting interference power at primary receivers is below a certain limit. This limit is due to the broadcast nature of wireless transmissions and the vulnerability of wireless communications to eavesdropping. The problem of secure transmission in the presence of an eavesdropper has been studied from an information-theoretic perspective in the literature. Recently, information-theoretic security has been investigated in fading multi-antenna and multiuser channels. For instance, cooperative relaying under secrecy constraints has been studied in the literature.

The text discusses the use of constrained density functional theory (CDFT) to study the adsorption of organic molecules on a 2D (2D) metal, specifically focusing on the charge transfer energies between a benzene molecule and a graphene sheet. The study involves three different configurations of the benzene molecule adsorbed on the graphene sheet: the hollow configuration, where all carbon atoms of the benzene ring are placed exactly above the carbon atoms of the graphene sheet, and the stack configuration, where alternate carbon atoms of the benzene molecule are placed directly above the carbon atoms of the graphene sheet. The CDFT approach is used to calculate the charge transfer energies, which are found to decrease as the distance between the molecule and the graphene sheet increases. The results show that the charge transfer energies are weakly affected by the presence of other molecules, and the presence of defects in the graphene sheet does not significantly alter the charge transfer energies. The study also provides a classical electrostatic model to explain the observed behavior of the charge transfer energies.

The study of complex networks has significantly increased in recent years, with applications ranging from computer science to biology to social science. The text discusses the development of an immunity system for detecting and defending against active p2p worms in the context of a p2p overlay network. The system employs phagocytes, which are a subset of p2p hosts with high immunity and can ``eat'' active p2p worms. The phagocytes monitor their managed p2p hosts' connection patterns and traffic volumes, detect worm events, isolate and patch infected phagocytes, and provide access control and filtering mechanisms for communication between the p2p overlay and external hosts. The system is designed to provide both internal defense and external protection against active p2p worms, utilizing phagocytes to detect and isolate worm attacks, and employing adaptive and interaction-based computational puzzles to prevent external attacks. The system is evaluated in a prototype system and validated in a massive-scale p2p overlay network with realistic p2p network traces.

The paper presents a new method for reading out the qubit state by current measurement in the doublet blockade regime, and analyzes the qubit dynamics in the presence of decoherence processes caused by interaction with the electrodes. The authors also consider the time dependent electron transport in the doublet blockade regime. The qubit dynamics is analyzed in the presence of leakage processes from the doublet to two electron states. The authors present the driven case where the mixing parameter between the doublet state is time dependent. The doublet blockade is partially removed and one can observe strong rabi oscillations. The authors also investigate mixing of the doublet subspaces with the spin flip processes in the electrodes. The text provides an overview of stochastic resonance, its definition, and its applications in various fields. It also discusses the concept of stochastic resonance and its role in improving signal transmission through channels. The text concludes by highlighting the importance of stochastic resonance in statistical literature and its potential applications in real-world scenarios.

The text discusses the measurement of the longitudinal thermal conductivity in two single crystals of yttrium barium copper oxide (YbCo) under a planar magnetic field rotated parallel to the CuO planes. Fourfold oscillations were observed below 88 K, while the angle dependence of the longitudinal thermal conductivity changed. The results are consistent with a model involving andreev scattering of quasiparticles by vortices and the brt expression for the thermal conductivity assuming a wave pairing. The agreement between the model and experimental data suggests that the mechanisms influencing the behavior of quasiparticles below 1 K and above 91 K are well described by the fermi liquid theory.

The text discusses the cosmetic surgery conjecture for knots in three-dimensional space, focusing on purely cosmetic surgeries along knots in the three-sphere. It presents a surgery formula by LeScop for a knot invariant, which is used to prove the cosmetic surgery conjecture for knots with no more than three crossings. The text also explores the cosmetic surgery problem for two-bridge knots and whitehead doubles, and provides an explicit formula for the invariant in the genus 83 case.

The paper discusses the potential of hypercharged anomaly-mediated SUSY breaking models at the LHC, focusing on the expected sparticle mass spectrum and branching fractions. It compares the expected reach of these models to existing models and highlights the similarities and differences between the models. The authors also discuss the implications of the mass ordering in the gaugino sector and provide a detailed analysis of the sparticle production cross section. Overall, the paper aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of the potential of these models and their implications for collider searches.

The text discusses the development and application of the zero-range potential (ZRP) approach, which allows for the creation of potentials with arbitrarily disposed discrete spectrum levels for any angular momentum. The ZRP is a boundary condition on the wavefunction that represents the scattering problem. The ZRP is typically represented as a pseudopotential (breit) and can be constructed using Darboux transformations. The text also discusses the use of Darboux formulas in multi-dimensional space and the application of Darboux transformations to dress the ZRP. The ZRP can be used to dress potential structures, such as the electron scattering by polyatomic molecules, and the results are presented in a graphical format. The text concludes by discussing the potential limitations of the ZRP approach and the need for further research to improve its accuracy.

The text discusses the numerical solution of initial value systems of two-dimensional convection-diffusion equations with both Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions using modified exponential cubic B-splines (MECBs) and modified trigonometric cubic B-splines (MTCBs). The methods are found to be stable for both space and time convection-diffusion equations, with cubic order accuracy for both Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions. The numerical results are compared with existing methods and show that the proposed methods are more accurate and agree well with the exact solutions.

The text discusses the discovery of a complex field of bright radio galaxies, with spectroscopic evidence suggesting a submm emission source. The authors note that the submm emission likely originates from two central radio components, which are most likely at redshifts of 3.036 and 3.037. The authors also discuss the possibility of a blended submm source, with the faintest radio counterpart detected at 3.5 mag. The authors conclude that the submm emission likely originates from the two central radio components, which are most likely at redshifts of 3.03 and 3.037.

The text discusses the evolution and environmental dependence of the galaxy luminosity function based on data from the norris survey of the corona borealis supercluster. It presents the results of the norris spectrograph survey, which includes measurements of the local field galaxy lf and the evolution of the population of blue, star-forming galaxies. The authors conclude that the norris survey provides a robust framework for understanding the evolution of the galaxy population, despite some differences between the local and field lfs.

The text discusses the rapidity gaps observed in hadronic collisions at the HERA and Tevatron colliders, which are attributed to color singlet quanta between incident partons. It highlights the importance of the color singlet exchange effect in qcd events, which is relevant at momentum transfers of order 1,000 gev. The paper proposes a two-gluon exchange model to describe the color singlet fraction, which grows with the color charge of the scattered partons. The model is unitarized, leading to a more realistic description of the color singlet exchange fractions. The unitarized model is shown to be nonperturbative, and its nonperturbative effects are summarized in terms of two parameters: the survival probability and a universal coulomb phase shift. The model is applied to the Tevatron data, and it is shown to describe the formation of rapidity gaps in hadronic scattering events. The paper concludes that the unitarized two-gluon exchange model is a viable theoretical framework for describing the rapidity gap data.

The text discusses the use of artificial neural networks (ANNs) for forecasting electric energy consumption in the Gaza Strip. It presents a proposed ANN model for predicting energy consumption for the year 2012 and 2013, which was evaluated using various error criteria. The study also highlights the limitations of traditional forecasting methods and the potential of ANN-based approaches in addressing these challenges.

The text discusses the detection of narrow emission lines in the bowen region of the compact object lmcx-2, which is a spectroscopic period in lmcx-2 that is close to previously published photometric periods of 8.15 hours by callanan et al. The detection of these narrow emission lines suggests that lmcx-2 is a z-source with an accretion rate around the eddington limit, while the 12-day period detected by crampton et al. is most likely the superhump period due to an inclined precessing accretion disk. The spectroscopic data set also indicates that the narrow emission lines are arising from the surface of the secondary, which could imply that lmcx-2 is a neutron star. The detection of these narrow emission lines provides new constraints on the system parameters of lmcx-2, including the mass function and the orbital period.

The text discusses the axial anomaly, its implications, and its potential applications in various theoretical frameworks, including gauge theories, including QCD. It also provides an overview of the current state of research on the axial anomaly and its implications for understanding the basic aspects of quantum field theory.

The text discusses the challenges and limitations of current salient object detection models, particularly those used on complex scenes like the Bruce and Judd datasets. It highlights the importance of explicit human saliency judgments in determining the most salient object, which is often misinterpreted by models. The authors propose a simple baseline model that assesses the accuracy of saliency map thresholding, while also exploring the dependency of results on saliency map thresholding and segmentation parameters. They also discuss the importance of unbiased salient object detection datasets and the need for more elaborate analysis of interplay between saliency detection, fixation prediction, and object proposal generation. The text concludes by emphasizing the need for a more diverse and elaborate analysis of interplay between saliency detection, fixation prediction, and object proposal generation.

<summary>Qwen has provided a combinatorial procedure for calculating the ranks of maps induced by two- and three-manifolds with boundary, including the case of cobordisms between two- and three-manifolds with boundary. The procedure involves constructing multi-point triple heegaard diagrams and using them to count holomorphic triangles in symmetric products. The paper also discusses the computation of maps induced by two- and three-manifolds with boundary, including the case of cobordisms between two- and three-manifolds with boundary. The results of this paper give an algorithmic procedure for computing the ranks of maps induced by two- and three-manifolds with boundary, including the case of cobordisms between two- and three-manifolds with boundary.</summary>

The paper extends the results of Yetter and Xcite by generalizing classical results of Gerstenhaber and Schack on infinitesimal deformation theory of associative algebras and poset-indexed diagrams of associative algebras to a deformation theory for arbitrary pasting diagrams of 0-linear categories. The authors establish the cocycle and cobounding conditions for obstructions in a deformation theory for arbitrary pasting diagrams, providing a framework for understanding deformations of associative algebras. They also describe a method for constructing deformation complexes of pasting diagrams in general, by first giving a detailed and rigorous exposition of a method developed by Shrestha. The authors then apply this method to prove that obstructions are cocycles in a family of deformation complexes sufficient to imply the result in general.

The text discusses the concept of the chiral constituent quark model, which is a simplified model of the strong interaction between quarks. It explains that the chiral interaction between quarks is responsible for the short-range repulsion in the nucleon, which is crucial for understanding the low-energy properties of the nucleon. The model also predicts that the chiral interaction between quarks is related to the fermi nature of constituent quarks and the specific interactions between them. The text also discusses the short-range interaction in other systems, such as the chiral limit of the pion-exchange interaction and the correlation of two-pion exchanges. The model provides a unified description of both the nonstrange and strange baryon spectra in good agreement with phenomenology.

The text describes a novel calcium phosphate-coated implantable medical device that minimizes immune response and allows for controlled drug delivery. The process involves sol-gel processing of calcium phosphate to produce a thin, flexible coating that can be deposited on a variety of metallic surfaces. The coating can be used to address adverse phenomena related to common medically implanted devices, such as restenosis after coronary stent placement.

The text describes a novel method for fabricating nerve guidance conduits (NGCs) that utilize integrated spiral structured porous sheets and electrospun fibers. The NGCs are tunable in terms of size and length, with the ability to be used for long gaps in nerve regeneration. The NGCs are designed to provide a stable, aligned structure that enhances nerve regeneration and neurite extension. The method involves placing a spiral structure on a rotator and spinning aligned nanofibers along the spiral structure to form outer fibrous tubes and guide spiral structures. The NGCs are tunable in terms of size and length, with the ability to be used for long gaps in nerve regeneration. The method also involves using electrospun fibers to provide structural support and improve nerve regeneration. The summary provides a brief overview of the key features and benefits of the NGCs, including their tunability, size and length, and their potential to enhance nerve regeneration.

The invention relates to seat base support assemblies for furniture or the like, including sinuous spring bands, wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, or flexible steel bands. The invention finds particular advantage in sinuous band seat spring assemblies, and is discussed initially in that context. The invention provides rail connectors that combine four essential seat-force-generators: torsion, dynamic uplift, expansion-contraction, and leverage-amplification. These combine to produce four desired seat-performance characteristics: initial-drop, deep-drop, softness, and resilient uplift. The rail connectors can be used with various types of spring bands, including helical, cantilever, and spring steel wire. The invention also provides seat base support assemblies that can be connected to other types of seat base support means, such as wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, or flat steel bands.

The text describes an anvil assembly for a surgical stapler, including an anvil head assembly, an anvil shaft, and a stabilizing collet. The collet is positioned to prevent damage to the anvil shaft and is positioned within a longitudinal bore defined by the flexible legs of the anvil shaft. The collet is also positioned to prevent damage to the anvil shaft caused by engagement of the anvil shaft with a grasper during coupling of the anvil assembly to the stapling device. The collet is cylindrical and includes a distal end with a plurality of cantilevered fingers that secure the collet within the longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft. The collet is positioned to prevent damage to the anvil shaft caused by engagement of the anvil shaft with a grasper during coupling of the anvil assembly to the stapling device.

The present invention provides a container of a blender, including a cup and a lining mounted inside the cup. The lining is shaped as a half-mask, which shields the inner wall of the receptacle from collision. Teeth are projected from the inner wall of the lining to grate fibers of vegetable and fruit. The lining is combined to the inner wall of the cup to form a shield screen. The cup has a handle and a spout, and the lining is embedded into the cup and combined to the cup integrally. The assembled view is illustrated as shown in 3D.

The text describes a garnish pick that includes appendages for skewering and holding a garnish, as well as hooks for accepting a rim of a food or beverage container. The garnish pick can be used to hold garnishes with one or more appendages emerging from a main shaft, angled toward a sharp end of the main shaft, that are used either to hook the pick to the rim of the glass or to skewer garnishes. The garnish pick can also be used to hold a rim of a beverage container. The appendages may project from a main shaft at different angles and/or orientations, and the hooks may be used to secure the garnish pick to a food or beverage container. The garnish pick can be asymmetric about any plane passing through the garnish pick, and can be used to hold a rim of a beverage container.

The present invention provides a cardiac assist system that combines a muscle-powered cardiac assist system with direct electrical stimulation of a heart. The system includes a device and algorithm for a combined cardiomyostimulator and cardiac pacer-cardioverter-defibrillator. The device senses cardiac events, measures intervals between events, and defines intervals for muscle stimulation. The system also includes a muscle stimulation burst that is delivered to the skeletal muscle wrap during a detected arrhythmia. The burst is designed to maintain cardiac output and prevent arrhythmias from interfering with reliable sensing of arrhythmia. The system also includes a muscle catch stimulation burst that is delivered to the skeletal muscle wrap during a detected arrhythmia. The text describes an IOL device that is designed to be implanted in the eye following a capsulorhexis to correct cataract vision. The device is resiliently biased to an unaccommodated state, with the IOL device having a first diameter d1 in the absence of radial compressive forces. The IOL device is configured to transmit most, if not all, of the accommodative power and the refractive power of the lens chamber to the base lens. The IOL device is also configured to reduce the overall diameter of the lens chamber and to cause opposing sides of the lens chamber to increase their curvature upon the application of a radially compressive force. The text describes an esophageal displacement electrode that can be inserted down the esophagus and into the stomach with a portion of the electrode in contact with the stomach wall in a position most favorable for electrically stimulating the ventricle of the heart in cooperation with an external electrode placed on the patient's chest. The electrode is capable of being moved close to the heart or other organ to reduce the energy required to carry out the particular procedure such as pacing or defibrillation. The electrode is made of a semi rigid plastic tube that can be inserted either orally or nasally into the esophagus and has a mechanism for deflecting the distal end of the tube to place it in pressurized contact with the stomach wall to cause a bulge that places the electrode in closer proximity to the ventricle.

The text describes a board game with a lake theme, featuring various elements such as lake areas, boats, dams, marinas, and marinas. The game involves players rolling dice to determine movement of tokens across a continuous path, with penalties and rewards for trespassing and buying properties. The game ends when all but one player is bankrupt, and the remaining player is declared the winner.

The text describes a new device and method for treating tissues and open wounds, including a device for active treatment and regeneration of tissues such as wounds. The device combines liquid fluid supply and suction, allowing for controlled tissue growth and drainage. The device can be used for non-regenerative tissue treatment and for regenerative tissue treatment. The device can be used for continuous suctioning through a separate drainage port or for intermittent suctioning through a separate drainage port. The text describes the design and features of a gravity-driven steerable wheeled vehicle, including its components, steering system, braking system, and alternative ski versions. It highlights the benefits of the vehicle, such as improved control and maneuverability, and the integration of various subsystems for enhanced performance.

The text describes a Radial Reflection Diffraction Tomography (RRDT) imaging method and apparatus that utilizes Hilbert space wave inversion to reconstruct images of objects surrounding a physical probe in a radial reflection configuration. The method involves collecting scattered energy waves from objects and processing them to produce images of the objects. The imaging method can be used to characterize vulnerable atherosclerotic plaque, track underground contaminants, and evaluate non-destructive parts with existing access holes. The method also incorporates elastography to gain further insight into the elastic properties of surrounding tissues and predict plaque composition. The imaging apparatus includes a flexible substrate and a Hilbert space inverse wave (HSIW) algorithm to map angular locations and frequency parameters of scattered energy waves to reconstruct images of objects. The imaging method can be combined with elastography for non-destructive characterization in other applications.

The present invention describes a biological oil composition, formulations comprising the oil composition, and the use of the oil composition in dietary supplements, functional foods and pharmaceutical products for the prevention or treatment of cardiovascular disease. The oil composition of the present invention differs from typical fish oil and krill oil in both gross chemical composition and fatty acid content. Despite its high wax-ester content, the oil composition of the present invention is a low-viscous and completely free-flowing liquid at room temperature. The copepod oil of the present invention has a markedly different biological effects than a concentrated preparation of EPA and DHA used in the same concentration as in the copepod oil. The copepod oil of the present invention prevents the formation of atherosclerotic plaque and is useful in the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease. The copepod oil of the present invention also has a notable effect on blood cholesterol level and is useful in the prevention and treatment of hypercholesterolaemia and elevated blood cholesterol levels. The oil composition of the present invention comprises from 20% to 75% by weight of wax esters, preferably 50% to 100% by weight of wax esters, and is isolated from a marine copepod, preferably Calanus finmarchicus. The oil composition of the present invention comprises from 5% to 20% by weight of SDA, and is further provided with 3-15% by weight of EPA and 2-10% by weight of DHA. The oil composition of the present invention further comprises 1000-4000 ppm of astaxanthin, mainly in esterified form.

The invention describes polyelectrolyte complexes containing active substances, which can be incorporated into microparticles for administration. The complexes can be prepared by mixing polyacids and polybases, or by using biocompatible polymers. The complexes can be prepared in various sizes, from microparticles to nanoparticles, and can be used for various therapeutic and diagnostic applications. The incorporation of active substances can be controlled by the composition of the complexes, and the release of the active substance can be controlled by the consistency properties of the complex. The invention also describes the use of polyelectrolyte complexes as air-containing echogenic contrast agents for ultrasonic diagnosis.

The text describes a golf ball teeing device that eliminates the need for manual unclamping of the golf ball and tee, allowing the golfer to tee up a golf ball without bending over. The device uses a golf club as a handle, reducing the weight and size of the device, and is simple to use with no cumbersome controls to release the tee and ball. It can easily and nonintrusively be clipped onto a golfer's apparel while hitting the ball, and can be easily attached to a golf bag. The device is made from fewer parts than prior tee setting devices, and can be made from various materials.

The text describes a person support apparatus for hospital beds, including a deck support frame with two legs pivotally connected at the head and foot ends. The apparatus includes a stabilizer element connected to each leg, a stabilizer cross-element for each leg, and a brake assembly for each leg. The apparatus also includes a brake lever connected to the brake assembly and a brake surface pushed downward by the foot of a care giver. The apparatus can be controlled by a foot operated pedal, a remote control, or other control mechanism. The apparatus can be used to raise or lower the deck support frame and the patient support surface, and can be used to move the deck support frame into the Trendelenburg or reverse Trendelenburg positions.

The application described is a reflectance measuring apparatus designed to measure skin reflectance. It comprises a probe with an aperture for light transmission, a flexible connection for optical fibers, and a measuring device with light emitting and receiving components. The apparatus is adaptable to measuring reflectance on various skin surfaces, including areas less than 1 cm. It is particularly useful for measuring the effect of anti-reflective products on greasy skin, particularly for assessing the efficiency of greasy skin treatments. The apparatus is also suitable for grading different types of skin, including greasy skin. The main features include a flexible connection for easy handling, miniaturization of the probe, and the ability to tolerate small deviations in relative position between the probe and the skin surface. The reflectance measurement is performed by comparing specular reflection and diffuse reflection, with the difference or quotient being used to calculate the reflectance value. The results are displayed on a screen, allowing the operator to view the reflectance value immediately and help in positioning the probe.

The invention provides a dental cleaning and massaging apparatus that includes a mouthpiece with upper and lower channel members that fit over the upper and lower teeth, respectively, and fit snugly against the respective gums. The apparatus includes a first or outer membrane that extends from the uppermost part of the upper channel member downward to the lowermost part of the lower channel member. The apparatus also includes a second or inner membrane that extends from the uppermost part of the upper channel member downward to the lowermost part of the lower channel member. The apparatus includes bite blocks located in both the upper and lower channel members, which are used to massage the gums. The apparatus also includes a hose or tube that connects the upper and lower channel members and provides air and water to clean and massage the teeth and gums. The apparatus can be operated with either air or cleaning fluid, and can be used with both air and water.

The text describes a pelvic floor reconstruction implant system and method. It outlines the design of a needle for threading straps of implants through tissue, with the needle being flexible like a brake cable and thin enough to occupy minimal surgery space. The system includes a surgeon's access to the pelvic area, with the surgeon inserting a finger into the vagina to separate ligaments and locate the implant on the desired threading point. The surgeon then penetrates the implant through ligaments and pushes it into the desired depth, releasing the looped end of the strap by toggling a toggle arm. The surgeon can then pull the implant back, leaving the looped end and strap at the side beyond, with tight shrinking of ligaments towards the threaded point.

The text describes a ventilator system for providing assistance to patients with respiratory issues, including spontaneous breathing, Cheyne-Stokes breathing, and hypoventilation syndromes. The system uses a fuzzy logic algorithm to adjust the degree of assistance based on the patient's breathing pattern and the severity of the breathing issue. The system also includes features for detecting and adjusting the timing of breathing, as well as features for treating apneas and hypopneas. The system is designed to provide a smooth pressure waveform that adjusts automatically to the patient's breathing pattern, and to provide a controlled amount of assistance to the patient. The system is particularly suitable for patients with severe lung disease who cannot easily be treated using a smooth physiological pressure waveform.

The invention describes a novel electro-surgical dissecting and cauterizing instrument for use primarily in laparoscopic/endoscopic procedures. The instrument includes a rigid arm extending between the distal, working tip electrode and the insulating sleeve. The arm includes portions laterally offset from the longitudinal axis of the sleeve, which reduces obstruction of the surgeon's view of the working tip electrode and surgical work site. The working tip electrode is formed at the free end of the arm and is used to make direct contact with the patient at the internal operation site. The insulating jacket is disposed upon the arm from the point where it extends from the sleeve to the working tip electrode.

The invention provides a magnetic resonance imaging apparatus that allows high-contrast exposures in a short time, even given an examination of larger body segments. The apparatus has a support plate arranged longitudinally within an examination volume, and a nuclear spin resonance apparatus with predetermined number of transmit and receive coils. The required adjustment parameters are determined in a preceding adjustment process, and the exposures are executed in a subsequent exposure process. The adjustment parameters are stored in a memory until the conclusion of the examination, and can be used again when identical or suitably similar exposure parameters (position of the support plate and configuration of the transmit and receive coils) are reached in the context of the same examination.

The present invention provides a releasable fastener for an album comprising front and back covers and removable pages between the covers, the fastener having a pair of strap anchors, one adapted to be attached to the front cover and the other to the back cover, a strap adapted to pass through aligned apertures in the covers and album pages from the strap anchor at the front to the strap anchor at the back, and means for providing a releasable connection between the strap and each of the strap anchors to enable insertion and removal of pages at the front and back of the album, the releasable connection permitting adjustment of the effective length of the strap between the anchors to accommodate a variable thickness of the album. The strap anchors are of variable length which can be adjusted within predetermined limits to suit the number of pages within the album. The strap is snap-locked into the channel by snapping engagement beneath locking lips at an open side of the channel facing the base of the channel, and the base of the channel and opposing surface of the strap have formations which are engaged to prevent longitudinal displacement of the strap within the channel when its in its engaged position beneath the lips. The strap enters into the channel via an aperture in the base of the channel and that aperture is bordered by a projection adapted to extend into the adjacent hole in the cover to ensure correct location between the strap anchor and the cover. The strap is of variable length which can be adjusted within predetermined limits to suit the number of pages within the album. The present invention provides a sulky construction that avoids traditional manual manufacturing processes by using casting and mass production with corresponding low expenses. The sulky is designed with lightweight construction, easy running, and strong construction to withstand strain during exercise and competitions. The sulky is assembled by a user himself from substantially flat elements requiring only a small space during storage and transportation, and the connections become secure without any play, even if the single components are produced with ordinary manufacturing tolerances.

The ventilation system for a rotating water feed includes a bypass arrangement with an inlet and outlet arranged between the feed duct and the discharge duct. The bypass is designed to remove air bubbles accumulating in rotating pipes such as water feeds of water-cooled generators. The bypass is arranged in the end face of the feed duct, with an inlet opening into the space around the axis of rotation. The bypass is also designed as a radially arranged pipe, with an inlet opening into the space around the axis of rotation. The bypass is structured to include means for increasing the hydrodynamic resistance of flow through the bypass. The various features of novelty of the invention are pointed out with particularity in the claims annexed to and forming a part of this disclosure.

The steering column according to the invention is adjustable in length and height or inclination direction. It is also adjustable in the length adjustment direction 8 and height or inclination adjustment direction 9. The jacket unit is prestressed with respect to the retaining part in the displacement direction parallel to the longitudinal axis of the steering shaft in the direction toward the vehicle front. The break-away connection between the jacket unit and the retaining part is realized by a shear bolt. The jacket unit is dislocated with respect to the retaining part in the length adjustment direction 8 and height or inclination adjustment direction 9. The break-away connection is released by a shearing-off or breaking-off of the shear bolt. The jacket unit is dislocated with respect to the retaining part in the length adjustment direction 8 and height or inclination adjustment direction 9. The break-away connection is released by a shearing-off or breaking-off of the shear bolt. The jacket unit is dislocated with respect to the retaining part in the length adjustment direction 8 and height or inclination adjustment direction 9. The break-away connection is released by a shearing-off or breaking-off of the shear bolt. The jacket unit is dislocated with respect to the retaining part in the length adjustment direction 8 and height or inclination adjustment direction 9. The break-away connection is released by a shearing-off or breaking-off of the shear bolt.

The present invention provides a method for installing flat, uncontoured glass panels in curved window openings of vehicles, including a method for flexing and applying adhesive sealant to achieve a conforming curvature of the glass panel.

The invention provides a continuous gas scavenger machine for removing oxygen from water, including a cylindrical gas scavenger machine with reduced height compared to a stripping tower with a sump for chemical scavenger treatment. The machine has a continuous cylindrical sidewall and can withstand substantial internal pressures. It includes a feed box or inlet chamber, at least a first gasification chamber, a second gasification chamber, and an outlet chamber. The outlet chamber may optionally provide an injection booster pump and level control. The machine has a plurality of gasification chambers, each with a vapor space above the liquid level. The machine includes mechanisms for ingesting and mixing gas into the liquid, creating a turbulent area, displacing the first gas to the vapor space, and removing the second gas. The machine may also include a chemical scavenger feed unit for dispensing a metered amount of a first gas scavenging chemical. The machine may also include a liquid level controller to regulate the rate of fluid entering the gasification chambers. The invention provides a continuous process for removing oxygen from water, with reduced vessel height requirements and reduced capital costs compared to separate stripping towers.

The packaging machine described in the text is a deep-drawing packaging machine that includes a rotating shaft arranged in the production direction of the machine. The shaft is connected to a drive mechanism, such as an electric motor or a servomotor, which converts the rotational movement of the shaft into a lifting movement of a tool member. The shaft is arranged in the production direction of the packaging machine, and the tool members are synchronized with one another through the movement of the shaft. The shaft is provided with transfer mechanisms that convert the rotational movement of the shaft into the desired movement of the tool members, allowing the tool members to be moved in parallel to each other. The shaft is supported by cross bars arranged in the frame of the machine, and the transfer mechanisms are arranged symmetrically with respect to the shaft. The packaging machine is designed to be compact and compact, with a compact structural design that allows for a wide range of work stations and tool members.

<summary>Disposable finishing article drive member assembly constructed in accordance with the principles of the present invention. The assembly includes a depressed center grinding wheel with a backing flange and a pressure cap. The pressure cap snaps into engagement with the backing flange and provides a secure attachment to the drive member. The drive member is lightweight, vibration-free, and less expensive than throw-away articles while meeting safety standards.</summary>

The invention relates to a hydraulic unit for a vehicle brake system. The hydraulic unit includes a housing block and a motor, which is shown only in FIG. 3. The hydraulic unit is characterized by a first conduit portion that extends downward from the eccentric chamber or cam element chamber 9, and a second conduit portion that extends downward from the conduit portion 101. The first conduit portion is made in the form of a bore that intersects the stepped bore 8 at its lowest point and forms a channel, while the second conduit portion is made in the form of a bore that intersects the contour of the stepped bore 8 and forms a channel. The first conduit portion is closed off by means of closure elements 106 and 107, while the second conduit portion is closed off by means of a sealing element 116. The hydraulic unit is characterized by a pressure equalization conduit between at least one spring chamber 30b, 31b and the interior 111 of the motor 4, which is formed by interstices between wires 120 of the cable 64 and a tubular cable sheath 121 that sheathes the wires 120. The cable sheath 121 is introduced into a further sealing sleeve 127, which is located inside a second plug part 128. The cable sheath 121 is connected at least indirectly to the connection cable 140 in a way that equalizes pressure; the connection cable 140 likewise comprises a cable sheath 141 and in this case a plurality of sheathed connection strands 142. The provisions described in detail thus directly prevent the invasion of water to the hydraulic unit 2 yet nevertheless provide a pressure equalization of interiors of the hydraulic unit 2 with the ambient atmosphere, and they moreover bring about the diversion of pressure fluid, entrained by pump pistons, into a region of the unit that is located far from vulnerable electrical parts of the hydraulic unit. This prevents electrolytically active ingredients that may be present in the pressure fluid from attacking electrical components or rendering them inoperative.

The invention relates to a power and free conveyor system that includes a third dog that is normally urged to an operative carrier pushing position but is held by the track out of operative position. The second and third dogs include cam projections that engage portions of the track to hold the second and third dogs out of operative position. The cam projections on the second dog extend oppositely to the cam projections on the third dog. The carrier can be selectively transferred across short or long distances by moving the second and third dogs successively to operative position. This allows selective transfer of the carrier over short or long distances, accommodating various systems where the transfer varies between short and long distances.

The text describes a new type of rail car center plate bowl liner that is self-lubricating and conductive, eliminating the need for additional grounding apparatus. The liner is made of ultra high molecular weight polyethylene and contains a conductive material such as carbon black. It is designed to meet static dissipation standards and is flexible and can be used in various configurations, including flat horizontal and full bowl designs.

The invention provides a valve assembly for dispensing viscous substances, such as sauces, salad dressings, mustard, catsup, etc., where one hand is used to hold the receiving vessel. The valve assembly includes a tubular sleeve adapted to be inserted into the spout of a bag or pouch, a dispensing package extending through the sleeve, and a guide extending radially outward from the sleeve. The guide carries a gate valve member that can be reciprocated to position it over the discharge or dispensing outlet. The gate valve member includes a curved guide plate that guides the gate member during its reciprocal movement relative to the outlet. The valve assembly can be mounted on the spout of a bag or pouch and can be used to dispense viscous substances in a fast-food restaurant setting.

The text describes a vehicular rearview mirror system that is tolerant of different protocols of an output of a vehicle control. The system includes an electro-optic reflective element that assumes a partial reflectance level in response to a drive signal. The system also includes a mirror control that is responsive to the output of the vehicle control for generating at least one mirror control output. The at least one mirror control output includes a value for the drive signal. The mirror control determines the protocol of the output of the vehicle control including monitoring the output of the vehicle control in attempting to conclude a state of the output of the vehicle control. The system may be used with various types of vehicles with modifications to the circuit.

The present invention provides an anti-lock braking system for motorcycles that employs an anti-dive device with a damped telescopic front suspension. The anti-dive device is responsive to the brake force applied to the front wheel and operates by tapping hydraulic pressure downstream of the anti-lock control unit or sensing and applying the actual reaction to braking force of the front wheel. This system minimizes vertical vibration of the chassis, facilitates front wheel braking, and improves braking efficiency.

The present invention describes improved movable partitions and bulkheads for separating and insulating cargo during transportation or storage. The partitions and bulkheads are designed to be easily divided into sections of varying sizes, allowing for the division of cargo areas into different temperature zones. The panels can be slidably attached to the rails, allowing for independent movement and removal. The panels can be equipped with hinged mechanisms for easy opening and closing, and can be secured with straps or other mounting mechanisms. The panels can be used to separate fresh food products from frozen or dry goods, and can be used to maintain different temperatures within the same trailer or cargo container.

The text describes a novel sanitizable rotary valve for separating and purifying biological macromolecules in pharmaceutical processes. The valve is designed to be semi-permanent and semi-sanitary, allowing for periodic sanitization and cleaning while maintaining sterile conditions. It is particularly useful for separating slow components from fast components in simulated moving bed chromatography.

The text describes a gas-liquid contacting tray and improved valve-tray assembly for higher efficiency operation. The invention includes a directional thrust valve assembly for a process column with a plurality of trays and downcomers. The valve assembly includes a circular disc with a first and second leg for directing liquid flow, and a valve cover mounted on the disc for selectively biasing the rear region of the valve upward against the liquid flow for facilitating initial, directionalized vapor flow. The valve assembly also includes a circular disc with a first and second leg for directing liquid flow, and a valve cover mounted on the disc for selectively biasing the rear region of the valve upward against the liquid flow for facilitating initial, directionalized vapor flow. The valve assembly also includes a circular disc with a first and second leg for directing liquid flow, and a valve cover mounted on the disc for selectively biasing the rear region of the valve upward against the liquid flow for facilitating initial, directionalized vapor flow.

The text describes a fluid pressure regulator assembly that reduces pressure differences between the high-pressure fluid entering the regulator and the low-pressure fluid exiting the regulator. The assembly includes a vane motor coupled to a fluid regulator, which converts pressurized fluid into mechanical power. The vane motor converts the pressurized fluid into movement of the vanes, which may then be converted into rotational and/or electrical energy. The assembly is inexpensive to manufacture and maintain, lightweight and portable, and can reduce the size and cost of a regulator needed to regulate the pressure of a fluid.

The invention describes a pallet system that supports a load of at least one tray having side supports. The system includes a pallet with raised parallel guide rails, end stops, and end plates. The guide rails are raised above the level of the weight-bearing area of the top surface of the pallet. The pallet system provides enhanced stability and rigidity when loaded and wrapped. The system also allows trays to be slid on and off, and is suitable for automated loading and unloading of trays.

The present invention describes an electrical driven flying saucer based on magnetic suspension, which includes a saucer shell, a saucer cabin, a rotary-wing system, and a control system. The rotary-wing system is a magnetic suspension electromotive rotary-wing system with magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels, an electromotive ring, a magnetic suspension shaft, and a magnetic suspension guide rail. The magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels are suspended in the space restricted by the electromotive ring, magnetic suspension shaft, and magnetic suspension guide rail, forming a repulsive or attractive magnetic suspension radial bearing based on the principle that like magnetic poles repel, but opposite magnetic poles attract. The magnetic suspension inner ring of the magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels and the magnetic suspension shaft form a repulsive or attractive magnetic suspension axial bearing based on the principle that like magnetic poles repel, but opposite magnetic poles attract. The magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels of the rotary-wing system, the electromotive ring, and the magnetic suspension shaft constitute a magnetic suspension electric engine. The electrical driven flying saucer based on magnetic suspension is designed to overcome the reactive torque of the rotary wings, making full use of the limited internal space of the saucer shell and designing a compact structure, reasonable layout, small weight, high motive power conversion efficiency, and easily manipulated and controlled. The two improvement solutions mentioned in the present invention overcome the problem of reactive torque under the precondition of meeting the foregoing requirements, and can realize stable and easy power control of the rotary wing.

The text describes streptavidin muteins, a process for producing these proteins using recombinant DNA technology, and the use of these muteins for isolation, purification, and determination of biological substances. It also discusses the advantages of using these muteins in affinity chromatography and purification methods, and provides examples of their use in various applications.

The text describes a method for synthesizing substituted guanidines using nickel catalysts, including guanylating amines or pyrrolidines with thioureas or isothioureas in the presence of nickel catalysts. The method involves guanylation reactions of various amines and pyrrolidines with N,N-tert-butoxycarbonylthiourea, and the results indicate that the nickel(0) derived from the nickel-boride acts as a catalyst during the guanylation reactions.

The invention provides an apparatus and method for continuously conducting an anodic oxidation and an electrolytic coloring of aluminum strips or wires without requiring a large amount of electrical energy. The invention includes an anodic oxidation bath composition containing a cathode and an anode, an electrolytic coloring bath containing a nickel salt, cobalt salt, copper salt, tin salt, and selenious acid, and an electric circuit for connecting the cathode and anode to a power source. The invention also includes a means for continuously supplying an aluminum strip or wire, an anodic oxidation bath, and an electrolytic coloring bath, and a means for passing the aluminum strip or wire continuously and successively through the baths. The invention provides an apparatus suitable for continuous formation of colored anodic oxide coatings on aluminum strips or wires, which can achieve excellent weatherability or fade resistance.

The present invention describes a process for producing transgenic plants or plant cells transformed on a chromosome with a DNA sequence of interest and capable of expressing a function of interest from said DNA sequence of interest. The process includes providing plant cells or plants with at least two different vectors, assembling a DNA sequence of interest from two precursor vectors, and selecting plants or plant cells expressing the function of interest. The invention also provides transgenic plants or parts thereof like seeds produced by the process.

The present invention provides a swash plate type compressor with a polyfluoro elastomer coating on the facial and end surfaces of the swash plate. The coating includes lubricious and load bearing additives to enable the polyfluoro elastomer-based coating to simultaneously provide the necessary durability and low coefficient of friction surface. The fluorocarbon coating is applied to the swash plate in a liquid spray and cured in an oven at an elevated temperature. The coating on the swash plate permits the use of low silicon alloy aluminum without the need of metal plating or high finish polishing. The coating exhibits very smooth facial surfaces and end surfaces, and is effective for use in swash plates with shoe gaps of between 0 to 0.000039 inches (0 to 1 m). The coating is not susceptible to machining and can be applied to hypereutectic aluminum without requiring high surface finish. The coating is durable and can be used in swash plates with shoe gaps of between 0 to 0.000039 inches (0 to 1 m).

The present invention provides novel chemical compounds suitable for use in anti-reflective coatings in photolithography processes for forming submicro-patterns using 193 nm (ArF) and 248 nm (KrF) light beams in the manufacture of semiconductor devices. The compounds are designed to facilitate light absorption at specific wavelengths, prevent standing wave effects, and eliminate rear diffraction and reflected light from lower layers. The anti-reflective coatings are prepared by dissolving a polymer of the general formula 1, 2 or 3 in an organic solvent, and adding one or more compounds selected from Tables 1a and 1b. The resulting anti-reflective coatings have proven to be excellent organic anti-reflective coatings during the formation of submicro-patterns in photolithographic processes using 248 nm KrF and 193 nm ArF lasers.

The invention provides a white, flame-retardant, UV-resistant, thermoformable, oriented film with a thickness in the range from 10 to 350 m, comprising at least one white pigment, at least one flame retardant, and at least one UV absorber. The film is produced using a crystallizable thermoplastic, and the thickness of the film is in the range from 10 to 350 m. The film comprises at least one white pigment and one flame retardant and one UV absorber, and has good orientability and thermoformability, and very good optical and mechanical properties. The invention further relates to the use of this film and to a process for its production.

The text describes a novel process for producing 143a, a hydrofluorocarbon with zero ozone depletion potential, by continuous gas phase hydrofluorination of 1,1-difluoro-1-chloroethane (142b) using a Cr/Ni/AlF3 catalyst. The process involves vaporizing 1,1-difluoro-1-chloroethane (142b) and HF, and then hydrofluorinating the resulting mixture to produce 143a. The process is efficient, selective, and yields high conversion and selectivity for 143a. The catalyst is a Cr/Ni/AlF3 catalyst, and the process can be carried out at high temperatures and pressures. The process is suitable for producing 143a in an economical, industrially feasible manner.

The text describes an improved process for the deacylation and desulfurization of a compound with the formula: ##STR3## by using hypophosphorous acid as a catalyst. The process involves heating the triazolothiadiazine precursors with hypophosphorous acid to produce hydrogen sulfide and the desired pyrazolotriazole. The process is characterized by reducing the amount of elemental sulfur and sulfur-containing organic impurities compared to the process without hypophosphorous acid. The process is suitable for preparing pyrazolotriazole compounds with low yield and high purity.

The text describes a method and apparatus for forming fiber mixtures from a plurality of fiber types by sequentially taking, from different fiber lots, a partial quantity which is small with respect to the entire quantity of the mixture. The method includes a fiber removing apparatus and a quantity measuring apparatus. The fiber removing apparatus includes a height-measuring device and a fiber quantity measuring apparatus. The quantity measuring apparatus includes a light barrier and a height-measuring device. The fiber removing apparatus is used to remove fiber from a series of stored fiber lots, and the quantity measuring apparatus is used to measure the height of the fiber bales. The method is adapted for obtaining a mixture of predetermined proportions of fiber types wherein the individual proportions are in each instance taken from a plurality of fiber bales. The method eliminates the disadvantages of the known process by providing a single fiber bale for each fiber type, measuring the height of the fiber bales directly, and removing fiber from the fiber bales in a predetermined number of passes. The method also provides a controlled and precise removal of fiber from the fiber bales, ensuring that the opening of all fiber bales is effected without fiber residuals and that an optimally homogeneous mixture is obtained.

The text describes a method and apparatus for forming bias laid, non-woven fabrics with parallel courses of yarns laid at an angle to the fabric direction. The method involves using a rake mechanism to accept and retain the yarns being carried by the yarn carrying means, and to place the yarns onto or between the appropriate needles on the conveyors of the fabric forming mechanism. The method also involves using a loose knitting operation to bond the yarns at their crossing points, and to apply a light resin spray to bond the fibers at their crossing points. The method is particularly useful for forming structural parts, such as in airplanes, and is used to wrap the fabric around a mold or to impregnate the fabric with a resin.

The text describes a multiple-color air jet loom with a weft insertion apparatus that uses different weft threads to insert and carry weft threads through warp sheds. The apparatus includes subnozzles with different orifice diameters and air pressure control means to produce different weft carrying forces for each weft thread. The apparatus also includes a weft insertion main nozzle and subnozzles for inserting and carrying weft threads. The weft carrying forces are regulated by varying the interval of time in which air is ejected, and the apparatus can be used with more than two different weft threads.

The text describes a process for producing bast fibres yarn, including steps for health-preserving bast fibres, carding, health-preserving bast fibre strips, and spinning bast fibre strips into bast fibre yarn. The process is designed to improve the flexibility and spinnability of bast fibres, reduce end breakage rate, and achieve low breakage rate. The text also mentions blending techniques for other fibres and the use of existing technologies for health-preserving bast fibres.

The text describes a method and apparatus for measuring and removing rotational variability from the nip pressure profile of a sensing roll used in nip presses. The method includes providing a sensing roll with sensors spaced at various cross-directional positions along its length. The sensors measure pressure exerted on the sensing roll by the web as it passes through the nip region. The pressure measurements are averaged to calculate the nip pressure profile. The method also includes providing corrective procedures to adjust for high or low pressure spots along the nip pressure profile. The apparatus includes a sensing roll with sensors spaced at various cross-directional positions, and a processor unit for calculating and displaying the nip pressure profile based on the pressure measurements. The apparatus also includes a wireless receiver for transmitting data signals from the sensors to a remote location, and a processor unit for calculating and displaying the nip pressure profile. The apparatus also includes a transceiver for transmitting data signals from the sensors to a receiver unit, and a processor unit for calculating and displaying the nip pressure profile. The apparatus also includes a display unit for providing a visual display of the nip pressure profile and the rotational variability profile. The apparatus also includes a method for sensing and removing the effects of rotational variability from the nip pressure profile of a sensing roll of a nip press.

The present invention provides an apparatus for supporting an electrical cord and storing an article, such as a spray starch can or a beverage container. The apparatus includes a releasable clamp for securing the cord to an ironing board, a flexible cord support for supporting the cord above the ironing board, and an article holder for holding the article. The clamp includes a retainer for retaining the flexible cord support on the clamp, and the article holder includes a lower circular hoop and vertical supports for spacing the hoop and supporting the article. The apparatus can be stored in a female electrical outlet for receiving a plug from an electrical cord.

The buttonhole controlling device of the invention includes a foot pad that attaches to a presser bar and a travelling assembly that includes a work engaging shoe and plate. The shoe and plate are separable parts that are held in assembled relationship with a wall on the plate extending upward through a slot in the shoe. The shoe includes an anchor element that is formed with a base and a horizontally extending helical spring that defines an initial position for the travelling assembly relative to the foot pad. The shoe is provided with a gaging element that includes a set of rails shaped to overlie and slide on the rails of the shoe and a tab for use in actuating tripping lever 20. When buttonholes are to be sewn, the material is placed between the shoe and plate, and the initial position of the travelling assembly is defined by springs that adjust screw 98. When screw 98 engages tripping lever 20, flexible contacts 22a, 22b open, and the machine is first caused to sew the top bar stitches a through aperture 106 in the foot pad. Following formation of the top bar stitches a, the machine sews left leg zig-zag stitches b as the travelling assembly and the material is fed in a forward direction by feed dog 108. Contacts 22a, 22b open, and the machine continues to operate without change until screw 98 engages tripping lever 20, and contacts 22a, 22b are opened and the machine continues to operate without change until screw 98 engages lever 20. When a perfect buttonhole is obtained, the operator can proceed to sew buttonholes in the garment of the same material. Whenever buttonholes are to be sewn in another garment of a different type of material, the screw 98 is readjusted while working with a sample of the new material before buttonholes are sewn in the new garment to compensate for possible slippage in different amounts of the different materials with respect to the travelling assembly.

The text describes a fabric treatment apparatus for treating dyed or printed textiles with a washing or rinsing solution. The apparatus includes a conveyor, a liquid applicator, a suction device, and a dwell stretch. The conveyor moves the textile web along a predetermined path, and the liquid applicator applies a washing or rinsing liquid to the web during motion. The liquid is removed by suction through the web and through the sieve belt. The dwell stretch is formed by a series of rollers arranged in a loop, allowing the web to be spread out and in a single layer. The web is then subjected to suction and washing treatment.

The dry cleaner is equipped with an air flow system that draws ambient or room air into the access opening whenever the door is opened. This system minimizes the escape of toxic solvent vapors from the tubs and retains solvent vapor in the interior of the tubs. The system is exclusive of the air recirculating system and reduces exhausting the residual solvent vapors from the tubs. The system is adapted to provide the air flow without exhausting the tubs, thus minimizing the loss of solvent vapor to the atmosphere.

The text describes a method and apparatus for forming fine continuous filaments and nonwoven webs using a quench chamber and a continuous two-dimensional slot. The method involves spinning a polymer filament into a quench chamber where it is contacted with air or other cooling fluid, drawn through a nozzle, and collected as a web on a conveyor belt. The apparatus includes a quench chamber, a continuous two-dimensional slot, and a vacuum suction box for pulling down filaments onto a moving mesh belt conveyor. The method and apparatus provide a flexible and efficient way to form fine continuous filaments and nonwoven webs, with improved web uniformity and isotropic properties.

The text describes a sewing machine and an embroidery unit that can be attached to and detached from a bed of a sewing machine. The embroidery unit includes an ultrasonic pen that can detect an ultrasonic wave transmitted from a marker affixed to a work cloth. The sewing machine can easily set a position on the work cloth at which sewing is performed. The sewing machine can also detect the ultrasonic wave transmitted from the ultrasonic pen and calculate the specified coordinates E based on the detection timing of the ultrasonic wave. The embroidery unit can be attached to and detached from the bed of the sewing machine, and the sewing machine can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can also move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth. The embroidery unit can move the embroidery frame to hold the work cloth

The present invention provides a preparation for application onto a cellulosic fabric or textile material, comprising a blended mixture of wool particles or wool powder and a binding agent, wherein the functional additive is carried by the wool particles. The preparation demonstrates exceptional carrying and retention capability for functional additives, enhancing the durability of functional enhancements of cellulosic fabric materials. The preparation is environmentally friendly and economical due to the use of ultrafine wool fibres. The method for preparing the preparation involves pulverizing wool into ultrafine powder, forming an ultrafine wool suspension, and adding functional additives. The method for preparing the preparation includes the step of pulverizing the wool powder into a suspension by ultrasonic crushing. The functional additive may include anti-UV agents such as zinc oxide or titanium dioxide, and may also include anti-bacterial agents such as nano-silver or zinc oxide. The preparation may be applied to a textile material, such as a cotton or linen fabric, and bonded to or deposited onto the fabric. The method for applying the preparation may include printing, padding, or foam application. The preparation may be provided with enhanced moisture management, wicking, and wrinkle resistance properties.

The present invention provides an automatic quilting machine for sewing individualized patterns into large fabrics such as bedspread or quilt. The machine includes a separate process controller to control the table movement and sewing needle movement, allowing reprogramming of individualized patterns without reprogramming the entire system.

The text describes a method for manufacturing a two-sided, three-dimensional image nonwoven fabric. The method involves providing a fibrous matrix and a second matrix, forming a precursor web, and hydroentangling the precursor web on a three-dimensional image transfer device. The precursor web is then imaged to form a nonwoven fabric with a three-dimensional image. The method also includes incorporating a support layer or scrim to enhance the three-dimensional image and improve the fabric's durability and softness. The nonwoven fabric can be used in various applications, such as home cleaning, personal hygiene, medical, and other end-use products.

The invention is a sewing machine with a guide chute for a strip of material that overlies the bed plate and feeds a workpiece material into association with the strip of material for sewing by the needle. The device includes a control setup with a stop arranged in the feed path of the strip for contacting and stopping the feeding thereof, which is displaceable out of the feed path and connected by control means to the sewing machine for controlling the operation of the sewing machine in accordance with the position of the stop and the strip material.

The text describes a connective knitting method for knitting two tape-shaped knit pieces, where the method involves knitting two tape-shaped knit pieces by a flat knitting machine with multiple needle beds, one or both of which are movable in the lateral direction. The method includes overlaying symmetrical loops of the final course of both knit pieces across the boundary and binding off the overlaid symmetrical loops gradually, repeating the step by a proper number of times depending on the width of the knit fabric until the two pieces are connected. The method also includes manually sewing the end portions of both knit fabrics to prevent loosening the stitch.

The text describes a traction element made of twisted steel fibres and a rectangular jacket made of flexible thermoplastic plastics material. The traction element is produced by unwinding stranded cables and sheathing them with the plastics material. The strands are coated with a layer of flexible thermoplastic plastics material to improve adhesion and reduce friction. The traction element is used for lifting and pulling loads, and has a wide range of applications, including lifting and pulling of loads. The traction element is produced by a production line consisting of a system with reels for unwinding the cables, a thread guide for the cables, and extruder for sheathing the cables. The traction element is marked when passing through an automatic or manually operated inscription device.

The invention provides a lockstitch sewing machine with a rotary hook arrangement that prevents the bobbin housing from rotating with the hook body. The rotary hook includes a bobbin housing, a bobbin capsule carrier, and a spring-loaded holding finger. The spring-loaded holding finger is arranged on the bobbin capsule carrier and is connected to the hook body by a spring rod. The spring-loaded holding finger prevents the bobbin housing from rotating with the hook body by bending back the spring rod when the bobbin housing is pulled back. This arrangement significantly reduces thread movement impediments during the looping process and allows for smoother needle thread movement.

The text describes a series of electrospinning experiments to produce silicon-based nanowire materials and composite materials. It outlines the electrospinning processes and post-deposition treatments for different ink formulations, including Si 6 H 12 /PMMA, Si 6 H 12 /QPAC100, Si 6 H 12 /Co 2 (CO) 10, PMMA/Si 6 H 12 /CdSe, PMMA/Si 6 H 12 /Carbon Black, PMMA/Si 6 H 12 /Graphite, PMMA/Si 6 H 12 /Ag, PMMA/Si 6 H 12 /AIP, PMMA/Si 6 H 12 /BBr 3, PMMA/Si 6 H 12 /PBr 3, and PMMA/Si 6 H 12 /CNTs. The experiments demonstrate the versatility of electrospinning for producing silicon-based nanowire materials and composite materials, including anode materials for lithium ion batteries.

The present invention provides an arrangement for controlling thread tension in a spool creel, comprising a plurality of controllers that are simultaneously settable by fluid pressure. Each controller is coupled to a different corresponding one of the spool holders, and each controller has a brake rotor and an adjustable, tension responsive braking element coupled to the brake rotor. The arrangement also has a tensioning lever coupled to the braking element for biasing it. The tensioning lever has a roller adapted to engage and be biased by the threads, and this tensioning lever is operable to occupy an angular position dependent upon thread tension and weight. The force generated by the preferred biasing arrangement operates in addition to the weight force on the tensioning lever, whereby the thread tension is also altered. When the warping machine is shut off, the braking force throughout the entire creel can be increased so that a quick braking action is possible. The biasing arrangement operates by fluid pressure, and it can influence the tensioning lever without hindering the swinging action of the tension lever necessary for the control procedure.
The present invention provides a low-price, durable sewing machine detector that minimizes stress on optical fibers and reduces the need for curved reflecting portions on reflective discs.

The process for the continuous production of viscose rayon yarns with a high degree of whiteness has been simplified, allowing for faster spinning and reduced space requirements, without sacrificing the desired degree of whiteness.

The text describes a patent application for a deaerator tank for bleaching pulp. The patent describes a cylindrical tank with an open top and flat bottom. The tank has an exterior diameter of 106.68 cm and a height of 211.46 cm. The inlet pipe has a center line between the top edge of the tank and the top of the tank. The outlet pipe has a center line between the bottom of the tank and the top of the tank. The filtrate from the pulp mat enters the tank through the filtrate swirler inlet. The height of the slurry in the tank is controlled by the height sensor at the bottom of the tank. The filtrate swirl inlet is located between the bottom of the tank and the nominal height of the pulp slurry. The emergency bypass line is also located between the bottom of the tank and the nominal height of the pulp slurry.

The invention describes a biomimetic tendon-reinforced (BTR) composite material with improved properties, including a very high out-plane stiffness and strength-to-weight ratio. The BTR composite is optimized using a topology optimization method, which transforms a static load problem into an equivalent material optimization problem. The resulting design is characterized by curved shapes suitable for different applications, and can be used to design new advanced materials with properties never thought possible. The BTR concept is extended to three-dimensional structures, and the use of hollow stuffer members and bent-wire tendons simplifies manufacture and may even be automated using pick-and-place robotics.
