The invention provides a method and a system for selectively connecting a wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local area network (WLAN) to a mobile terminal. The WWAN contains a plurality of first base stations, each covering a distance of about 2 to 10 km in a normal GSM system. The WLAN contains at least one second base station for gathering service information of the first base stations. The second base station can be an access point. The access point has a GSM module for scanning the broadcasting information of the neighboring first base stations. The first wireless module can turn off and the second wireless module can turn on when the mobile terminal connects the WLAN. The first wireless module can turn off and the second wireless module can turn on when the mobile terminal connects the WWAN. The invention provides a method for a mobile terminal to select a serving base station of a wireless wide area network (WWAN) in a communication system. The communication system contains the wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local network (WLAN) and the mobile terminal can be a dual mode mobile terminal for using in the WLAN and the WWAN which are independent.

The text describes a new process for producing multilayered components, including the use of flexible decals to prepare carriers, the use of multiple first and second electrodes and electrical components to form sub-assemblies, and the use of electro-therm inks to deposit components onto decal surfaces. The process eliminates the need for cutting steps and allows for the provision of a variety of tab configurations and coil structures, as well as the provision of a line of capacitors adapted to use with semiconductor devices. The process is adaptable to a number of other electronic ceramic devices, including multilayer ferrite inductors and multilayer substrates with buried metal circuitry.
The text describes a hierarchical lattice structure with improved specific stiffness and strength, including various embodiments and applications.

The text describes a process for co-producing power and hydrocarbons using a coal-to-liquid (CTL) hydrocarbon synthesis facility and an Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) facility. The process includes a dry gasification stage, a gas clean-up stage, a first Fischer-Tropsch hydrocarbon synthesis stage, a second Fischer-Tropsch hydrocarbon synthesis stage, a heavy end recovery stage, a water gas or sweet shift stage, a CO 2  removal stage, a hydrogen separation stage, a reaction water treatment stage, a product work-up stage, and a waste heat recovery stage. The process benefits from economies of scale in the capital intensive parts and provides for CO 2  sequestration. The process is integrated with an air separation unit to provide intermediate streams suited to hydrocarbon synthesis and power production respectively. The process is suitable for internal consumption of energy or for maximizing economy of scale for the export of power. The process is also suitable for capturing CO 2  from the off-gas of the IGCC facility.

The present invention provides a method for preparing a superconducting device, which includes forming a blocking film over the surface of the superconducting material to prevent the removal of oxygen from that portion. The method also includes adding oxygen to the surface or portion close to the surface of the superconducting material to create a highly reliable surface utilizing device. The superconducting material is typically a metal oxide, and the method can be used to fabricate Josephson devices. The method also includes using a blocking film to prevent oxygen from being removed from the surface or portion close to the surface of the superconducting material. The superconducting material can be used to fabricate Josephson devices, such as Josephson elements, with long-term stability and high reliability.

The present invention provides a compact apparatus for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination. The apparatus includes a base structure for stabilization and a clamping arrangement for gripping the foam sheet sample without damaging it. The apparatus permits precise measurements of the sample cross-sectional specimen and provides a method for examining the individual cells within the foam structure. The apparatus also allows for the preparation of samples with at least two parallel cut edges, preserving the structure of the cells and enabling even transmission of light during microscopic examination.

The text describes a novel method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination of a seismometer on the ocean floor. The method involves suspending a geophone at the end of a shaft protruding from a ball rotating in an annular seat to form a free moving pendulum. A spring-loaded plunger is positioned above the ball and restrained from contact with its surface by a pin that passes perpendicularly through the plunger and is connected to a linearly acting solenoid. After deployment, the solenoid is activated by an acoustic command unit to align the plunger and the geophone, preserving the angle of inclination assumed by the seismometer during operation. The method also includes a method and apparatus for automatically leveling seismic motion detectors used in a seismometer on the ocean floor.

The text describes a humidity sensing element for gaseous fluids, which is suitable for excitation by a ten Hertz sine wave alternating current voltage and consists of a tubular aluminum first electrode member with an anodized layer impregnated with nickel particles by vacuum deposition. The sensor is designed to respond to changes in relative humidity by varying the impedance between the electrodes, which is proportional to the relative humidity. The sensor is self-contained and forms its own protection for the humidity-sensitive portion in its bore, while the surrounding atmosphere may circulate freely through the bore. The impedance of the sensor varies inversely proportionally to the relative humidity, and the response time is approximately 1 second. The sensor is tested for linearity and performance in a range of temperatures and humidities, and is found to be effective for commercial humidity controls.

The text describes a motor assembly with a force transmission structure comprising a drive plate and a shaft. The drive plate has a mounting hole and a shaft fitted to the mounting hole for rotation with the drive plate. The drive plate has a plurality of protrusions formed on a first side of the body and configured to engage with a driving member, the shaft further comprises a pinion configured to drive a driven member. The drive plate further comprises a plurality of ribs formed at an opposite second side of the body. The drive plate is made of an engineering plastics material and the damper is made of rubber. The shaft further comprises a pinion for driving a gear of a window lift system. The drive plate is held captive within the mounting hole by a circlip located within a groove in the distal end of the toothed portion. The force transmission structure is designed to solve the problems of conventional gear trains and improve the transition between the drive plate and the shaft.

The present invention provides a method and system for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver. The system includes an antenna, a radio frequency subsystem, and a baseband subsystem. The baseband subsystem generates a mobile time reference using a high frequency clock and a low frequency clock. During active mode, the mobile time reference is provided to the baseband subsystem, which uses the high frequency clock to generate the mobile time reference. In idle mode, the mobile time reference is provided to the baseband subsystem, which uses the low frequency clock to generate the mobile time reference. The baseband subsystem maintains the mobile time reference using the high frequency clock and the mobile time reference as a starting point. The baseband subsystem also provides control signals to the RF subsystem, which provides a mobile time reference to the portable transceiver. The baseband subsystem also provides control signals to the WCDMA modem, which provides a mobile time reference to the portable transceiver. The text describes a helmet liner that is individually fitted to a wearer's head using a custom-fitting method. The liner is made of four layers of thermoplastic sheets, each with an array of pockets that deform in response to compressive contact with an adjacent layer. The liner is heated to a plastic state and placed between the outer shell and the wearer's head to deform the sheets to the proper extent. The liner is then removed when the sheets have cooled to a rigid, nonplastic state. The liner is adjustable to accommodate a changed head size, and it does not require trimming or drawstrings during fitting.

The invention relates to a multiorifice structure spray disc for atomizing fuel in an internal combustion engine. The structure is made by fusing concentric layers of solid rods interspaced with cylindrical members, and the method for making the multiorifice structure comprises fusing concentric layers of alternating cylindrical members and angularly disposed rods into an integral assembly, and slicing such integral assembly in a direction normal to the axis of said cylindrical members to produce a plurality of multiorifice structures, wherein the interstices between the rods and cylinders form a plurality of angularly disposed passageways.

The text describes a method for fabricating an insulated gate field effect semiconductor device (IGFED) with a low density n-type region (LDD) structure. The method involves forming an insulating film on the gate electrode, ion injection of an impurity using an oxide film of the gate and an insulating film as a mask, and then anisotropically etching away the oxide film to leave a portion on the sidewall of the gate. The method also includes ion injection of an impurity using an insulating film on the gate as a mask, and anisotropically etching away the oxide film to form a high density n-type region. The method also includes ion injection of an impurity using an insulating film on the gate as a mask, and anisotropically etching away the oxide film to form a low density n-type region. The method also includes ion injection of an impurity using an insulating film on the gate as a mask, and anisotropically etching away the oxide film to form a high concentration n-type region. The present invention provides an improved radio telephone that can be connected to a PC and used as an improved IP telephone. The enhanced radio telephone includes an internal speech coder which is implemented for low power consumption and allows it to be used with a relatively low-performance PC for effective IP telephony. The enhanced radio telephone handset is convenient for speech conversation and reduces the above described echo problems which are commonly associated with conventional IP telephones. The enhanced radio telephone can selectively operate as either a conventional radio telephone or as an improved IP telephone. The enhanced radio telephone is also used for wireless data communication in order to carry IP speech. The present invention provides an improved IP telephone which is more convenient, economical and efficient than conventional IP telephones.

The invention relates to a process and an apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine. The process involves using an optical checking element to detect a plurality of cigarettes located in the magazine, evaluating the scanned image by an image-processing device, and producing an error signal if the scanned image deviates from a reference image or reference value. The apparatus includes an optical checking element arranged in the magazine and an image-processing device for evaluating the scanned image. The error signal can be produced if the scanned image deviates from a reference image or reference value. The process and apparatus can be used to automatically eliminate disruptions in the magazine, such as transversely located cigarettes, and to register defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarettes.

The text describes a simplified connection system for high voltage cables, including an outer cone concept and a no cone or slight inner cone concept. The outer cone concept separates the cable connection further from the apparatus it is connected to, reducing the likelihood of a fault affecting the other side. The system also simplifies complete alignment of meeting surfaces without risking glow discharges.

The invention describes a fixing mechanism for a tool, comprising a tool, a tool frame, and a bushing-like tool holder. The fixing mechanism can be used for fixing both the actual machining tool and its counterpart, i.e. the so-called cushion, to the tool holder in the frame of the machine tool. The mechanism can be used for machining, particularly in sheet machining centers, and is particularly advantageous for use in cutting, punching, moulding, and forming work, particularly in metal sheets in so-called sheet machining centers.

The text describes a switching circuitry method and apparatus that can generate high efficiency and low noise supply voltages for display drivers. The method includes creating multiple circuit paths that carry electric current in opposite directions to cancel out radiated noise. The apparatus includes reducing EMI by using terminal leads at the periphery of the circuit. The method and apparatus can produce sufficient current to drive large displays without generating EMI, and can be used to drive touch screens on Apple devices.

The text discusses the differences between the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 (LDA) and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) definitions for lobbying activities. LDA includes a comprehensive list of subjects for lobbying contacts, while IRC section 4911 and section 162(e) do not. The text also highlights the exceptions to the IRC section 4911 lobbying definition, including exceptions for contacts made during routine government business and for contacts made by public officials acting in an official capacity.

In 2002, GAO reported that leading companies committed to a strategic approach to acquiring services, moving away from numerous individual procurements to a broader aggregate approach. Strategic sourcing can encompass a range of tactics for acquiring products and services more effectively and efficiently. Companies have made structural changes to their services acquisition processes, with top leadership support, such as establishing commodity managers responsible for purchasing services within a category. Strategic sourcing can also leverage data to identify opportunities for cost savings and improve performance.

The text discusses the current challenges faced by the nation's surface transportation programs, including declining reliability and the need for increased funding. It outlines principles for restructuring and funding surface transportation programs, including identifying national public interests, developing up-front analysis criteria, and exploring freight transportation options. The text also highlights the need for a comprehensive approach to addressing transportation challenges, including increased reliance on contractors and the potential for improved intermodal transportation.

The costs associated with each of these activities generally depend on the nature and usage of the specific service FAA provides. The Postal Service, the nation's largest civilian employer, had about 765,000 career employees at the end of fiscal year 1997. The Postal Service's Diversity Development Department, established in 1992, was tasked with creating a diverse workforce. The study, conducted by Aguirre International, found that women and minorities were underrepresented in higher EAS positions, particularly in EAS 17 and above positions. The study also found that women and minorities were underrepresented in the lower EAS positions, particularly in EAS 11 through 16 positions. The Postal Service's Diversity Program, which includes training and contracting with minority-owned businesses, was identified as a model for other organizations.

The Food Stamp Program, a federal program that provides food stamps to low-income households, has undergone several changes and options to improve access and reduce reporting burdens. These changes include the introduction of electronic benefit transfer systems, the simplification of eligibility and reporting requirements, and the alignment of food stamp and TANF work requirements.

The provided text outlines HUD's budget request for fiscal year 2000, which includes several new initiatives and programs. HUD is proposing an increase in its Section 8 housing assistance program, which includes a $209 million request for the CDBG Program. The budget justification for this request shows that HUD's estimates of the unit costs of some project-based housing are substantially higher than HUD projected just a year ago. The budget proposal also shows that HUD's estimates of Section 8 costs in the years following 2000 are not provided. Additionally, HUD is proposing an increase in its EZ Program, which includes $45 million that would be distributed to the 15 communities that were designated as Strategic Planning Communities.

The text discusses the development and documentation of facility requirements for the replacement medical center, including inconsistencies and errors in patient workload and staffing data, and the need for DOD to revise its documentation to provide clear support for how it developed its facility requirements.

This summary provides a concise overview of the review conducted by the author to assess how ICE ensures discretion in the alien apprehension and removal process. The review examined whether ICE has designed internal controls to guide and monitor officers' exercise of discretion, and whether ICE has developed mechanisms to ensure consistent dissemination of legal developments. The summary also highlights the need for ICE to develop time frames for updating policies, guidelines, and procedures, and to establish mechanisms to analyze trends in the use of discretion.

The text discusses the findings of a report on ambulance services, including the costs and expected Medicare payments for ground ambulance transports. The report provides a detailed analysis of the costs and expected Medicare payments for ambulance transports in different service areas, including urban, rural, and super-rural areas. The report also examines the relationship between ambulance transports and the volume of transports, the intensity of Medicare transports, and the use of volunteer staff. The report concludes that the costs and expected Medicare payments for ambulance transports can be better targeted to trips in less densely populated areas, where the volume of transports and intensity of Medicare transports are lower.

The report discusses the management of sensitive conventional arms, ammunition, and explosives (SRC I ammunition) by the Department of Defense (DOD). It highlights the challenges faced by the military services in maintaining accountability and visibility of SRC I ammunition, including issues with physical inventories, satellite tracking, and system updates. The report recommends several actions to improve accountability and visibility, including revising guidance on accountability, improving satellite tracking, and ensuring timely data entry into DOD information systems.

The provided text discusses the disclosure policy of the Social Security Administration (SSA) for law enforcement and the Privacy Act. It compares SSA's disclosure policy with that of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and the Bureau of the Census. The report includes site visits and interviews with SSA officials, law enforcement officials, and other relevant parties to gather data on law enforcement requests for personal information. The report also provides a detailed survey of SSA's policy on law enforcement requests, including the types of requests, response times, and methods for handling requests.

The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) is a federal law that governs the management of hazardous waste from its generation to its final disposal. RCRA establishes requirements for hazardous waste management, including identification and listing of hazardous waste, treatment and storage, and permitting. The report analyzed the barriers to managing remediation waste under RCRA, including the bright-line approach and the CAMU rule. The report recommended that comprehensive reform of RCRA's requirements for managing remediation waste be addressed through legislative action.

The text discusses the allocation and funding of Medicare program integrity activities, including audit, medical review, secondary payer, benefit integrity, and provider education. It provides details on MIP funding ranges, expenditures, allocations, and ROI calculations for fiscal years 1997 through 2005. The report also examines CMS's approach to allocating MIP funds, including changes in the Medicare program that may affect MIP funding allocations, and interviews CMS officials regarding factors they consider when allocating MIP funds.

The text discusses the performance of passenger and checked baggage screeners at U. S. airports, including the need for ongoing training and improvements in screening effectiveness. TSA has implemented several measures to enhance screening performance, including the development of performance indexes, the use of TIP for checked baggage screening, and the implementation of a short-term screening performance improvement plan. However, the text notes that TSA has not yet finalized performance targets for several key performance measures, and that the agency plans to continue implementing TIP for checked baggage screening. The text also highlights the importance of ongoing training and the need for a clear plan for prioritizing and scheduling the deployment of high-speed Internet/intranet connectivity to all airport training facilities.

IRS faces significant challenges in providing telephone customer service to taxpayers, including inadequate staffing, inaccurate demand forecasting, and ineffective scheduling practices. To improve its human capital management practices, IRS should establish a long-term, desired service-level goal based on taxpayers' needs, set annual goals for progress toward that goal, and develop a system for assessing competency gaps and refresher training needs. Additionally, IRS should consider the effects of its human capital practices on overall service goals and interrelationships among its toll-free service human capital practices.

Ginnie Mae, a secondary market entity, faces challenges in fulfilling its mission of supporting government-backed loan programs in a changing market environment. The agency has expanded its product offerings and taken other initiatives to maintain its viability. Ginnie Mae must adequately disclose loan information that MBS investors need to assess prepayment risk. Ginnie Mae must work within the limits of its commitment authority. Ginnie Mae must ensure adequate liquidity for its MBS portfolio. Ginnie Mae must avoid rationing its commitment authority, which could cause disruption among secondary market participants and harm its credibility. Ginnie Mae must address data integrity issues and improve internal controls to ensure accurate and effective contract management.

The provided text discusses the ongoing efforts by the Defense Department (DOD) to correct illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments made during fiscal years 2000 and 2001. The report includes a detailed analysis of the corrective actions taken by DOD officials, including the review of 162 adjustments reported as illegal or otherwise improper, and the monitoring of DFAS Columbus' review of $291 million of the $1.9 billion of closed account adjustments DOD reportedly made during fiscal year 2001. The report also examines the reasons for DOD's numerous adjustments to closed accounts, including the lack of basic controls and managerial attention required to properly account for its disbursements consistent with the 1990 account closing law. The report concludes by proposing options for Congress to address the long-term problems and eliminate illegal or otherwise improper closed account adjustments.

The text discusses the transition of the Internet domain name system from a government-funded project to a private, nonprofit corporation. The transition includes the creation of a new nonprofit corporation to manage the domain name system, the privatization of domain name system management, and the development of a process for external review of decisions. The transition has been ongoing for several years, with ICANN issuing its first status report in 2000. The transition has been met with controversy, with some arguing that the transition was not fair to the U.S. government and others arguing that it was necessary to improve the stability and security of the Internet.

The text discusses the implementation of trust reforms by the Department of the Interior (Interior) for American Indian tribes, including the establishment of a trust reform office, the development of a trust reform plan, and the implementation of trust fund management reforms. It highlights the challenges and opportunities presented by the 1994 Act, including the need for a timetable for completing trust reforms and the importance of maintaining a workforce plan that reexamines the responsibilities and needs for trust fund operations. The text also mentions the Special Trustee's recommendations for improving congressional oversight of the trust reforms and the need for a reexamination of OST's workforce needs.

In 1998, following a presidential call for VA and DOD to start developing a "comprehensive, life-long medical record for each service member," the two departments began a joint course of action aimed at achieving the capability to share patient health information for active duty military personnel and veterans. The first initiative, undertaken in that year, was the Government Computer-Based Patient Record (GCPR) project, which aimed to create an electronic interface that would allow physicians and other authorized users at VA and DOD health facilities to access data from any of the other agency's health information systems. The interface was expected to compile requested patient information in a virtual record that could be displayed on a user's computer screen. In our reviews of the GCPR project, we determined that the lack of a lead entity, clear mission, and detailed planning to achieve that mission made it difficult to monitor progress, identify project risks, and develop appropriate contingency plans. In 2001, we recommended that the participating agencies (1) designate a lead entity with final decision-making authority and establish a clear line of authority for the GCPR project and (2) create comprehensive and coordinated plans that included an agreed-upon mission and clear goals, objectives, and performance measures, to ensure that the agencies could share comprehensive, meaningful, accurate, and secure patient health care data. In 2002, we recommended that the participating agencies revise the original goals and objectives of the project to align with their current strategy, commit the executive support necessary to adequately manage the project, and ensure that it followed sound project management principles. VA and DOD took specific measures in response to our recommendations for enhancing overall management and accountability of the project. By July 2002, VA and DOD had revised their strategy and had made progress toward being able to electronically share patient health data. The two departments had refocused the project and named it the Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program and, consistent with our prior recommendation, had finalized a memorandum of agreement designating VA as the lead entity for implementing the program. This agreement also established FHIE as a joint activity that would allow the exchange of health care information in two phases.

The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) uses nine audit standards to evaluate the quality of audits, including the scope, techniques, technical conclusions, workpaper preparation, reports, and time management. The IRM defines audit quality as the determination of the correct taxable income and tax liability of the person or entity under audit. IRS uses a review of ongoing audit work to ensure that audit workpapers meet the quality standards. The IRM requires group managers to review workpapers during audits to ensure that audit standards are being met. The IRM also requires supervisors to document managerial involvement in the audit process.

The provided text discusses the challenges and limitations of the U.S. Foreign Assistance Agency (ATA) program, which aims to enhance the capabilities of friendly countries in counterterrorism efforts. The text highlights that the program lacks clear, systematic assessments of its effectiveness, which makes it difficult to determine the overall impact of its assistance. It also notes that the program lacks a clear, measurable sustainability measure, which makes it challenging to assess its long-term effectiveness. Additionally, the text criticizes the lack of guidance from S/CT and DS/T/ATA on how to prioritize and allocate limited resources, and suggests that the program should be more transparent and data-driven. The text concludes by recommending that the U.S. government should comply with congressional mandates to report on its international counterterrorism assistance.

The text discusses the status of large financial company bankruptcies, including recent changes to the U.S. Bankruptcy Code and efforts to improve cross-border coordination for the liquidation and reorganization of failed large financial companies. 1. OMB and Treasury have begun standardizing data elements across the federal government.
2. Independent auditors have reported material weaknesses, significant deficiencies, and other challenges in selected audits.
3. OMB and Treasury have established a Data Standards Committee to develop clear policies and processes for data standards.
4. OMB and Treasury have issued guidance on data governance and data standards.
5. OMB and Treasury have collaborated on a pilot design for the DATA Act, which includes a procurement portion.
6. OMB and Treasury have requested that non-Chief Financial Officers Act of 1990 (CFO Act) agencies submit updated implementation plans.
7. OMB and Treasury have established mechanisms to assess the results of independent audits and reviews of agencies' compliance with the DATA Act requirements.
8. OMB and Treasury have improved the pilot design for the DATA Act, including adding explanatory language and documenting data collected through the certified payroll reporting portal.

OSC, an office within Treasury's Bureau of the Public Debt, has an agreement with ARC, an office within Treasury's Bureau of the Public Debt, to provide contracting support for a fee. As a member of the Treasury franchise fund, ARC does not receive direct appropriated funds, but instead relies on revenue from its federal agency customers to pay organizational expenses. The agreement between ARC and OSC is a mechanism for interagency contracting. This type of fee-for-service procurement process generally involves three parties: the agency requiring a good or service, the agency placing the order or awarding the contract, and the contractors that provide the goods and services. The requiring agency officials determine the goods or services needed and, if applicable, prepare a statement of work, sometimes with the assistance of the ordering agency. The contracting officer at the ordering agency ensures that the contract or order is properly awarded or issued (including any required competition) and administered under applicable regulations and agency requirements. If contract performance will be ongoing, a contracting officers representativegenerally an official at the requiring agency with relevant technical expertiseis normally designated by the contracting officer to monitor the contractors performance and serve as the liaison between the contracting officer and the contractor. While interagency contracting can offer the benefits of improved efficiency and timeliness, this approach needs to be effectively managed. Due to the challenges associated with interagency contracts, we recently designated interagency contracting as a governmentwide high-risk area. As authorized by OSCs appropriation, OSC may use 5 U.S.C.  3109 to hire intermittent consultants. Section 3109 permits agencies, when authorized by an appropriation or other statute, to acquire the temporary or intermittent services of experts or consultants. Under the statute, appointments of experts and consultants may be made without regard to competitive service provisions and classification and pay requirements. Individuals appointed under this authority may not be paid in excess of the highest rate payable for a GS-15 unless a higher rate is expressly provided for by statute or an appropriation. Under section 3109, OPM is responsible for prescribing criteria governing circumstances in which it is appropriate to employ an expert or consultant and for prescribing criteria for setting pay. Section 3109 of title 5 and OPMs implementing regulations in 5 C.F.R. Part 304 provide for broad discretion in the appointment of experts and consultants. The provided text discusses the mission and challenges of the Veterans Administration (VA) in promoting the health, welfare, and dignity of all veterans. The VA is responsible for providing medical care, benefits, social support, and lasting memorials to veterans. The text highlights the department's three major components: the Veterans Benefits Administration (VBA), the Veterans Health Administration (VHA), and the National Cemetery Administration (NCA). The VA's IT infrastructure is critical to its efforts to provide benefits and services to veterans. The text also mentions the department's IT challenges, including the development of new systems, modernization of existing systems, and increasing interoperability with DOD. The VA faces challenges in key areas, including the development of new systems, modernization of existing systems, and increasing interoperability with DOD. The text concludes by emphasizing the importance of effective IT management in the VA's mission.

The Medicare program, with over 33 million beneficiaries and processing a high volume of claims, is unique in its authority and responsibility among health care payers. HCFA, an agency within HHS, is responsible for paying and monitoring more than 400 managed care health plans that serve more than 5 million beneficiaries. The agency is also responsible for reforming Medicare, including developing new health plan types and requiring the dissemination of information about these plans to beneficiaries. Despite these efforts, HCFA faces challenges in implementing its reforms and ensuring that contractors are paying only medically necessary or appropriate claims.

The text discusses the administration's proposal to align FAA's budget accounts with FAA's lines of business, which aims to better link costs and revenues. It highlights the challenges and potential drawbacks of this proposal, including the difficulty in defining safety-related activities and the potential for increased borrowing to fund capital investment. The text also mentions the complex nature of the proposal and the need for further analysis and time to reach a consensus on its soundness.

GSA's Federal Technology Service, in conjunction with the IMC, is responsible for ensuring that federal agencies have access to telecommunications services and solutions needed to meet mission requirements. The company awarded two contracts for long-distance services in December 1998 and January 1999, with each firm guaranteed minimum revenues of $750 million over the life of the contracts.

The text discusses the efforts of FSA, a government agency, to improve its performance and accountability in administering student financial aid programs. It highlights the need for FSA to improve its reporting of progress towards its goals, including unit cost calculation and system integration efforts. Additionally, it emphasizes the importance of ensuring that FSA's workforce is adequately prepared to meet future challenges and accomplish its mission.

The text discusses the recovery act grant awards made by the National Institutes of Health (NIH) and the information gathered from these grants. It provides details on the types of jobs supported by NIH Recovery Act funding, the number of FTEs supported, and the metrics used to track these impacts. The report also includes information on the number of FTEs supported by NIH Recovery Act funding, the number of FTEs supported by other grants, and the metrics used to track these impacts.

The text provides a detailed analysis of transit-oriented development in six cities, focusing on the extent to which transit-oriented development has occurred near selected transit lines that received federal funds and the factors or local government policies that support or hinder transit-oriented development. The case studies selected were Central Corridor Light Rail in Baltimore, MD; South Corridor Light Rail in Charlotte, NC; North Corridor Light Rail in Houston; TX; Third Street Light Rail, Phase 1 in San Francisco, CA; Tasman West Light Rail Extension in Santa Clara County, CA; and Green Line Metrorail Extensions in Washington, DC, and Prince Georges County, MD. The analysis included site visits, interviews with local officials, developers, and other stakeholders, as well as reviewing state and local planning regulations, transit ridership data, and literature related to transit-oriented development. The report found that transit-oriented development has occurred near some transit lines, but the extent of this development varies by city and local government policies. FTA considers factors related to potential transit-oriented development when assessing proposed projects, but the reliability of land use and transit ridership data is assessed through review of relevant laws and FTA's Annual Report on Funding Recommendations and New Starts policy guidance.

The Social Security Act introduced the PEBES in 1988 to improve workers' access to earnings records and benefit estimates. Since then, SSA has revised the PEBES to make it more user-friendly and less complex. However, the PEBES still contains too much information and is too complex for some people to understand. To improve the PEBES, SSA needs to revise its design and explain complex programs and benefits in simpler language.

The text discusses the challenges faced by disability beneficiaries who work, including the difficulty in determining their eligibility for both the Disability Insurance (DI) and Supplemental Security Income (SSI) programs. It outlines the need for improved guidance and procedures to address this issue, including developing training for field office employees, improving cross-references in program guidance, and developing fact sheets for concurrent beneficiaries. The report also recommends the development of public information materials to explain the complex interaction of the two programs and to ensure timely actions and minimize overpayments.

The text discusses the challenges faced by the federal government in tracking and reporting on the use of funds provided through four emergency supplemental appropriations acts for hurricane relief and recovery efforts. It highlights the need for a framework to collect and consolidate information on the status of these funds, as well as the importance of providing timely and reliable reports to both the Congress and affected states and taxpayers.

FAA has authority to authorize UAS operations in the national airspace, including military, public, and civil entities. The agency provides access to the airspace through three means: Certificates of Waiver or Authorization (COA), Special Airworthiness Certificates in the Experimental Category, and Special Rules for Certain Unmanned Aircraft Systems. The agency plans to use this approach to facilitate further incremental steps toward integrating UAS into the national airspace system.

The text discusses the challenges and needs of the United States in Afghanistan, particularly in managing and overseeing the Commander's Emergency Response Program (CERP). It highlights the difficulties in providing adequate training and oversight for CERP personnel, the lack of a centralized project-development database, and the need for coordination and oversight of CERP projects with USAID. The report also emphasizes the importance of improving management and oversight of CERP, including the need for a workforce assessment to determine the number of personnel needed to effectively manage and oversee the program.

The text outlines the findings of a report on solar energy initiatives supported by federal agencies in fiscal years 2010 and 2011. It identifies 65 solar-related initiatives across six federal agencies, focusing on photovoltaic, concentrated solar power, and solar hot water technologies. The report identifies key characteristics of these initiatives, including their focus on different types of solar technologies and their various technology advancement activities, ranging from basic research to commercialization. It also highlights the coordination activities among the initiatives, with some overlapping in key characteristics and goals. The report concludes by discussing the extent of fragmentation, overlap, and duplication among the solar-related initiatives, as well as the extent of coordination among these initiatives.

The text discusses the Department of Defense's risk assessment process for chemical and biological defense equipment, which is based on the number of individual items required to support operations. The report includes a detailed analysis of the inventory management practices of the services, including the use of contract, lot number, and expiration date information to determine the number of servicemembers scheduled for deployment who need protection. The report also highlights the challenges of managing risk within limited resources and the need for industrial surge capacity to make up any shortfall in required ensemble components. The report concludes by recommending that the Secretary of Defense direct the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics to issue and implement guidance requiring each service to evaluate its risk on the basis of current inventory numbers of complete ensembles against wartime requirements, implement a fully integrated inventory management system, and cease counting equipment as on hand before delivery from the contractor.

The text discusses the findings of a survey of 4,395 federal managers from 24 CFO Act executive branch agencies, including a 2017 survey on organizational performance and management issues. The survey included questions on factors influencing evaluation use, including the presence and use of performance information, agency climate, and program evaluation use. The survey results compared to previous surveys and provided insights into the current state of evaluation use in federal agencies. The report also analyzed the impact of GPRAMA provisions on agency evaluation capacity and the use of program evaluation.

The text discusses the challenges faced by the federal government in achieving the goals set by the Rehabilitation Act, including the need for agencies to develop plans for hiring and retaining individuals with disabilities, and the importance of regular reporting on progress towards these goals. It also highlights the need for agencies to improve their recruitment and retention efforts, including providing flexible work schedules, telework, and other reasonable accommodations. The text emphasizes the importance of providing comprehensive training on the tools available to agencies, including Schedule A hiring authority, to help improve outcomes.

BLM's mission is to manage public lands and resources for the American people. The Bureau, which is part of the Department of the Interior (DOI), has 210 state, district, and resource area offices that manage about 270 million acres of public lands located in 28 states, primarily in the West and Alaska. BLM's fiscal year 1995 appropriation totaled $1.24 billion. In fulfilling its mission, BLM develops land-use plans to balance multiple uses and competing demands, including ecosystem management, timber harvesting, mining, oil and gas production, watershed management, wildlife management, and recreation. It also designates and maintains land of critical environmental concern and is responsible for a major section of the National Spatial Data Infrastructure. In performing these functions, BLM maintains over 1 billion documents, including land surveys and surveyor notes, tract books, land patents, mining claims, oil and gas leases, and land and mineral case files.

The text discusses the U.S. government's efforts to strengthen safeguards and nuclear security programs, including the use of radiation detection equipment, to address concerns about nuclear proliferation. It highlights the challenges faced by the U.S. in implementing these programs, including corruption and coordination issues. The text also mentions the need for additional cooperation from other countries to address the challenges of nuclear smuggling and the need for a comprehensive approach to nuclear nonproliferation.

The text discusses the challenges faced by federal agencies and state-level organizations in addressing the Year 2000 computing crisis, including the need for significant leadership and partnerships, the importance of data exchanges, and the need for robust testing and contingency planning. It also highlights the need for federal and state data exchanges to be Year 2000 compliant, as well as the importance of ensuring that critical core business processes are adequately tested and that federal agencies have a complete and accurate picture of Year 2000 progress.

The text discusses the implementation of the Information Quality Act (IQA) by examining the number, type, and source of IQA requests, as well as the impact of IQA on agencies and the rulemaking process. It also includes interviews with OMB officials and IQA officials to assess OMB's role in implementing the act.

The text discusses the impact of mutual funds on deposits and the movement of money from deposits to mutual funds. It provides statistical data on the movement of money from deposits to mutual funds, including the total net flows into mutual funds and the impact on deposits. The report also examines the relationship between deposits and overall economic activity, as measured by GDP. The authors conclude that a reasonable estimate of the impact of mutual funds on deposits is sizable but probably less than $700 billion.

The text discusses the progress of major federal IT initiatives designed to strengthen the effectiveness of the public health infrastructure, including surveillance and communication systems. It analyzes agency documents, interviews officials, and compares CDC and DHS IT initiatives to identify key IT challenges and discuss the need for federal leadership in implementing standards and coordinating IT efforts.

The survey of large sponsors of DB pension plans revealed that they have made revisions to their benefit offerings over the last 10 years. Respondents reported that they modified benefit formulas, converted some plans to hybrid plans, or froze some plans. For example, 81 percent of responding sponsors reported that they modified the formulas of one or more of their DB plans.

The provided text discusses the process of refugee resettlement and integration into the United States, focusing on the recommendations made by the U.S. government and various organizations. Key recommendations include providing consultation and monitoring services, establishing a preferred communities program, and providing funding for employment and other social services for refugees.

The National Flood Insurance Program faces financial challenges, including inadequate funding, implementation challenges, and operational inefficiencies. To address these issues, Congress should consider measures to improve financial controls and oversight, encourage private sector participation, and address fundamental operational and managerial issues.

The text discusses the implementation of the 287(g) program by the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) Office of State and Local Coordination (OSLC). It provides an overview of the program's objectives, implementation, and resources used by participating agencies. The text highlights that ICE has designed controls to govern the program's implementation, including conducting background checks, providing formal training, and agreeing with state and local agencies to MOAs. It also discusses the resources provided by ICE to participating agencies, including equipment and training, and the activities, benefits, and concerns reported by participating agencies. The text concludes by noting that while ICE has designed controls to govern the program's implementation, it lacks a roadmap for achieving its objectives and the specific performance measures required to ensure program success.

The text discusses SEC's examination of mutual funds and broker-dealers, including changes to its mutual fund examination program. It provides information on how SEC, NASD, and NYSE share information, including written examination guidance, related to their mutual fund examination program. The text also discusses how SEC distributes and stores examination guidance for use by its broker-dealer examiners, and how it tracks and assesses such training. Additionally, it provides information on how SEC, NASD, and NYSE share written guidance related to mutual fund sales practices, and how they coordinate their examination efforts. The text also discusses how SEC, NASD, and NYSE coordinate in overseeing broker-dealers, and how they generally do not provide copies of their written examination materials to each other.

The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) reports on debt using a measure of total financing obligations that includes bonds and notes, which TVA considers "statutory debt," and other financing obligations including lease-leaseback obligations, energy prepayment obligations, debt related to variable interest entities, and membership interests issued in connection with a lease financing transaction. TVA's debt is reported as $26 billion in fiscal year 2016, including about $24 billion in bonds and notes and $2 billion in other financing obligations. TVA's pension liabilities, assets, and funded status are also reported.

The text discusses the review of First City Bancorporation of Texas's 1988 and 1992 resolutions, focusing on the lessons learned from the First City experience and the potential impact of FDIC's open bank assistance on the insurer and regulators' processes. It highlights the importance of understanding the factors contributing to the banks' failures and the need for improved oversight and resolution processes.

The source document discusses the importance of single audits in federal grant awards, highlighting the need for improved audit quality and accountability. It presents findings from a study conducted by the Single Audit Act Committee, which found that single audits are not being conducted in accordance with professional standards and requirements. The report recommends revisions to OMB Circular No. A-133, the AICPA Statement on Auditing Standards, and the AICPA Audit Guide to improve audit quality. It also suggests developing minimum content requirements for training and conducting a dialogue with cognizant and oversight agencies to address unacceptable audits.

Medicare is a federal health insurance program designed to assist elderly and disabled beneficiaries. It covers inpatient hospital, skilled nursing facility, hospice care, and certain home health services. Medicare contracts with intermediaries and carriers to process claims, and the agency has experimented with functional contracting to improve program management. The Social Security Act allows Medicare to deviate from the FAR under provisions of the Social Security Act enacted in 1965.

The text discusses the findings and recommendations of a report by the Defense Science Board (DSB) on outsourcing logistics activities. The report, which was prepared by the Defense Science Board Task Force on Outsourcing and Privatization, estimated that DOD could realize savings of 30 to 40 percent of logistics costs and achieve broad improvements in service delivery and responsiveness by outsourcing support services traditionally done by government personnel. The report also found that DSB's $6 billion annual logistics savings estimate was overstated by about $1 billion and another $3 billion in projected savings would be difficult to achieve or unlikely to be achieved.

The text discusses the Federal Workforce Restructuring Act of 1994 and its impact on federal employment levels, including the reduction of 272, 900 FTE positions in the United States between 1993 and 1996. It also highlights the streamlining of government operations and the reengineering of work processes at various agencies. The text emphasizes the importance of open communication and employee input in maintaining performance during downsizing.

The program includes casebuilding, classification, and calibration processes to ensure accurate and consistent data collection. IRS has also conducted site visits to field offices to review and improve the program's implementation.

The report assesses HHS's efforts to protect Medicare beneficiaries' protected health information (PHI) when data on prescription drug use is used for purposes other than their direct clinical care. It identifies OCR's responsibilities for protecting PHI and reviews OCR's enforcement activities, including periodic audits and de-identification guidance.

The MHSS, a military health care provider, has a mission to provide medical support to active-duty military personnel and maintain the health of the military. The MHSS has a demonstration project to train clinical psychologists to prescribe psychotropic medication, which has increased the number of MHSS mental health care providers who may prescribe drugs. However, the PDP implementation faced several problems, including the lack of a clearly defined purpose for prescribing psychologists, difficulty recruiting participants, unspecified selection criteria, repeated changes in the classroom curriculum, delays in granting prescribing privileges, and unresolved issues involving supervision. The PDP did not clearly define the role of prescribing psychologists in the MHSS. The ACNPs PDP evaluation panel noted in 1992 that the projects goal to train psychologists to issue appropriate medication under certain circumstances was rich with ambiguities. The project was structured and revised without specifying the prescribing psychologists duties and responsibilities, types of clinical settings or facilities their skills would be best suited for, types of psychotropic medication psychologists would be qualified to prescribe, and level of supervision they would require. The PDP did not clearly define the role of prescribing psychologists in the MHSS. The project was structured and revised without specifying the (1) prescribing psychologists duties and responsibilities, (2) types of clinical settings or facilities their skills would be best suited for, (3) types of psychotropic medication psychologists would be qualified to prescribe, and (4) level of supervision they would require. In September 1995, after the project had operated for 4 years, the ACNP panel suggested that DOD define clearly how PDP graduates could be used; this did not take place. Another enrolled in the medical school at USUHS. The third left because of dissatisfaction with the program. The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) is a large, deployable, infrared-optimized space telescope designed for a 5-year mission to find the first stars and trace the evolution of galaxies from their beginning to their current formation. JWST is being developed by Northrop Grumman, Harris, and the Space Telescope Science Institute (STScI). The project is divided into three major segments: the observatory segment, the ground segment, and the launch segment. The hardware configuration created when the Optical Telescope Element and the Integrated Science Instrument Module are integrated, referred to as OTIS, is not considered an element by NASA, but it is categorized as such for ease of discussion. JWST is dependent on software to deploy and control various components of the telescope as well as collect and transmit data back to Earth. The elements, major subsystems, and software are being developed through a mixture of NASA, contractor, and international partner efforts. The project is currently on schedule with 8.75 months of schedule reserve remaining. However, all of JWSTs elements and major subsystems are within weeks of moving onto the projects critical path, potentially reducing schedule reserve further. This is a tenuous position for the project given that it must complete five integration and test periods, three of which have not yet started. Testing can uncover problems that can be difficult or time-consuming to resolve, thereby adding schedule risk to the project and the unusual complexity of JWST further heightens these risks. To achieve mission success, the project will have to address over 100 technical risks and ensure that the projects potential areas for mission failure are fully tested and understood before project launch in October 2018. Overall project schedule reserve, currently at 8.75 months, remains above Goddard requirements and the projects planwhich was set above the Goddard standard at the replan in 2011 and included more reserve than required. However, as shown in figure 4 below, the use of schedule reserve on any element or major subsystemtwo of which have entered integration and testing phasesmay reduce the overall project schedule reserve. While some use of schedule reserve is expected, the proximity of each element and major subsystem schedule to the critical path means that the project must prioritize the mitigations when problems occur. The text discusses the lack of federal security requirements for chemical facilities and the need for additional legislation to address chemical sector security. It mentions that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has concluded that its existing patchwork of authorities does not permit it to regulate chemical industry effectively. The text also notes that the Congress should enact federal requirements for chemical facilities, as the existing laws do not provide any new regulatory authority to DHS. Additionally, it suggests that additional federal legislation is needed to place federal security requirements on chemical facilities, as the extent of security preparedness at these facilities remains largely unknown.

The major requirements for the protection of personal privacy by federal agencies are specified in two laws, the Privacy Act of 1974 and the E-Government Act of 2002. The Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 (FISMA) also addresses the protection of personal information in the context of securing federal agency information and information systems. The Privacy Act places limitations on agencies collection, disclosure, and use of personal information maintained in systems of records. The act describes a record as any item, collection, or grouping of information about an individual that is maintained by an agency and contains his or her name or another personal identifier. It also defines system of records as a group of records under the control of any agency from which information is retrieved by the name of the individual or by an individual identifier. The Privacy Act requires that when agencies establish or make changes to a system of records, they must notify the public by a system-of-records notice: that is, a notice in the Federal Register identifying, among other things, the type of data collected, the types of individuals about whom information is collected, the intended routine uses of data, and procedures that individuals can use to review and correct personal information. Among other provisions, the act also requires agencies to define and limit themselves to specific predefined purposes. For example, the act requires that to the greatest extent practicable, personal information should be collected directly from the subject individual when it may affect an individuals rights or benefits under a federal program. The provisions of the Privacy Act are largely based on a set of principles for protecting the privacy and security of personal information, known as the Fair Information Practices, which were first proposed in 1973 by a U.S. government advisory committee; these principles were intended to address what the committee termed a poor level of protection afforded to privacy under contemporary law. Since that time, the Fair Information Practices have been widely adopted as a standard benchmark for evaluating the adequacy of privacy protections. Attachment 2 contains a summary of the widely used version of the Fair Information Practices adopted by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in 1980. The E-Government Act of 2002 strives to enhance protection for personal information in government information systems and information collections by requiring that agencies conduct privacy impact assessments (PIA). A PIA is an analysis of how personal information is collected, stored, shared, and managed in a federal system. More specifically, according to Office of Management

The text discusses the effects of various Social Security reform elements and protections on disabled workers and dependents, including individual reform elements, certain protections, and the potential for benefit reductions. It also compares benefits to a standard of adequacy and discusses the need for a more direct comparison of disabled beneficiaries and retired beneficiaries.

The text discusses the status and challenges of various TARP programs, including the Troubled Asset Relief Program, and the ongoing efforts to address conflicts of interest and improve oversight of servicers. It also highlights the ongoing challenges of implementing the Making Home Affordable program and the need for improvements in internal control over financial reporting.

The text discusses the ongoing efforts by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Department of Energy (DOE) to monitor industry progress in responding to the four EPA regulations affecting coal-fueled electricity generating units. The agencies have taken initial steps to implement recommendations from a July 2012 report, including joint monitoring efforts and coordination with key industry stakeholders. However, stakeholders, including a FERC Commissioner, continue to express concerns about reliability and electricity prices. The report will be available on the GAO website at http://www.gao.gov.

While many estates are kept open for legitimate reasons, FSA field offices do not systematically determine the eligibility of all estates kept open for more than 2 years, as regulations require. FSA field offices conduct annual determinations, but the quality of determinations varies. The extent to which FSA field offices make eligibility determinations varies from state to state, which suggests that FSA is not consistently implementing its eligibility rules. FSA field officials have identified several instances in which FSA's lack of management controls resulted in improper payments to deceased individuals.

The text discusses the progress of the FAA's modernization program, which includes the development and implementation of various systems and technologies. It highlights the challenges and delays faced by the agency, including the need to update outdated systems and address issues related to dates and record-keeping. The text also mentions the need for a comprehensive system of performance measurements to help FAA assess its progress and make necessary adjustments.

During fiscal years 1993-98, the United States funded rule of law programs and related activities in countries throughout the world. Over this period, rule of law assistance totaled at least $970 million. The Latin America and the Caribbean region received the largest share, with about 36 percent. Africa, Central Europe, and the newly independent states of the former Soviet Union received about 15 percent each.

The text discusses the use of government-run franchise funds by the Department of Defense to provide common administrative services to federal agencies. It outlines the operating principles of the franchise funds, including the requirement to recover full costs, the establishment of performance measures, and the ability to adjust capacity and resources. The text also highlights the challenges faced by the franchise funds in ensuring fair and reasonable prices and providing good value to customers.

The text discusses factors affecting federal-nonfederal collaboration aimed at reducing wildland fire risk to communities, including collaboration on implementation of the Cohesive Strategy, increasing collaborative planning, expanding education, and improving timber-processing capability. It also highlights the importance of improving implementation of the Cohesive Strategy, increasing collaborative planning, expanding education, and improving timber-processing capability.

The Foundation, a private nonprofit organization, was founded in 1985 as the U.S. Committee for the Battle of Normandy Museum. It is tax-exempt under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and is not part of the U.S. government. The Foundation's activities include promoting public awareness of the historical significance of America's participation in the liberation of Europe, including the Memorial Garden to commemorate D-Day and the Battle of Normandy. The Foundation has also provided financial support for a French-owned and operated World War II memorial museum in Caen, France, and has sponsored a Normandy scholar program. The Foundation has also planned and promoted a Wall of Liberty in Normandy to honor World War II veterans involved in the European theater of operations. The Foundation has experienced significant managerial, financial, and internal control problems, and its liabilities substantially exceed its assets.

The text discusses the challenges and risks faced by public and private sector pension plans in investing in hedge funds and private equity, including the lack of uniformity among these investments, the potential benefits and risks, and the need for regulatory oversight. It provides a detailed analysis of the survey data and interviews with representatives of 26 private and public sector DB plans, including the Arizona State Retirement System and Missouri Local Government Employees' Retirement System. The report also includes a performance audit conducted from June 2007 to July 2008, in accordance with generally accepted government auditing standards.

This text provides an overview of the challenges and opportunities for Medicaid and CHIP programs in the territories of American Samoa, CNMI, Guam, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands, highlighting the differences in eligibility, funding, and program integrity efforts.

The text discusses the process of assessing hazardous waste sites for potential listing on the National Priorities List (NPL) and the characteristics of these sites. It provides a detailed analysis of 3,036 potentially eligible sites, including 1,789 sites that remain potentially eligible for the NPL. The report includes information on the characteristics of these sites, including their health and environmental risks, and the status of actions to clean up these sites. It also analyzes the opinions of EPA and other federal and state officials on the likely final disposition of these sites, including the number of sites that are likely to be added to the Superfund program. The report also includes a detailed analysis of the conditions at 1,739 potentially eligible nonfederal sites and 50 potentially eligible federal sites.

The text discusses the challenges faced by the United States in managing visa wait times and the need for a strategy to address these issues. It provides a detailed analysis of State's efforts to address visa wait times, including the use of consular staff, data analysis, and staffing and facility planning. The report also highlights the need for a long-term strategy to address visa demand and the potential for temporary measures to cope with projected increases in demand. The text emphasizes the importance of maintaining security responsibilities while facilitating legitimate travel to the United States.

OPM's mission is to ensure a federal civilian workforce with effective retirement programs. The Clean Air Act, enacted in 1963, sets national ambient air quality standards for pollutants such as ozone, carbon monoxide, particulate matter, sulfur oxides, nitrogen dioxide, and lead. The act was amended in 1970 to include new standards for hazardous air pollutants and to establish a market-based approach to reducing emissions. EPA has set national standards for ozone, carbon monoxide, particulate matter, sulfur oxides, nitrogen dioxide, and lead. The act directs states to specify how they will achieve and maintain compliance with these standards. The 1990 amendments to the act include a requirement for EPA to review and revise the national health- and welfare-based standards for air quality.

The United States concluded a free trade agreement with Oman on October 13, 2005, which was signed by USTR Bob Portman and Omani Minister of Commerce and Industry Maqbool bin Ali Sultan on January 19, 2006. The U.S.-Oman FTA is the fifth U.S. bilateral free trade agreement with a country in the proposed Middle East Free Trade Area (MEFTA). The entire proposed MEFTA is included in the map in Figure 1, with Oman, heavily shaded, in the lower right hand corner. The FTA with Oman is similar to other recent FTAs with MEFTA countries (Morocco and Bahrain), with slight variations. The U.S.-Oman FTA has three basic parts: new tariff schedules for each country, broad commitments to open markets and provisions to support these commitments, and protections for labor and the environment.

The Pacific Islands region, also known as the South Pacific or Southwest Pacific, faces a diverse array of policy issues. It is a strategically important region that encompasses U.S. Pacific territories. U.S. relations with Australia and New Zealand include pursuing common interests in the Southwest Pacific, which also has attracted Chinese diplomatic attention and economic engagement. Congress plays key roles in approving and overseeing the administration of the Compacts of Free Association that govern U.S. relations with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. The United States has economic interests in the region, particularly fishing. The United States provides foreign assistance to Pacific Island countries, which are among those most affected by climate change, particularly in the areas of climate change adaptation and mitigation. The Southwest Pacific covers 20 million square miles of ocean and 117,000 square miles of land area (roughly the size of Cuba). The region includes 14 sovereign states with approximately 9 million people, including three countries in "free association" with the United Statesthe Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. Papua New Guinea (PNG), the largest country in the Southwest Pacific, constitutes 80% of region's land area and 75% of its population.

The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP programs are briefly described, with Medicare being the nation's health insurance program for persons aged 65 and over and certain disabled persons. In FY2008, the program will cover an estimated 44.6 million persons (37.3 million aged and 7.3 million disabled) at a total cost of $456.3 billion. Federal costs (after deduction of beneficiary premiums and other offsetting receipts) will total $389.7 billion. In FY2007, federal Medicare spending will represent approximately 13% of the total federal budget and 3% of GDP. Medicare is an entitlement program, which means that it is required to pay for all covered services provided to eligible persons, so long as specific criteria are met. Medicare consists of four distinct parts: Part A (Hospital Insurance, or HI); Part B (Supplementary Medical Insurance, or SMI); Part C (Medicare Advantage, or MA); and Part D (the new prescription drug benefit added by the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement, and Modernization Act of 2003, or MMA, P.L. 108-173 ). The program is administered by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) in the Department of HHS. Medicaid is a means-tested entitlement program that finances the delivery of primary and acute medical services, as well as long-term care, to more than 63 million people at an estimated cost to the federal and state governments of roughly $317 billion. Each state designs and administers its own version of Medicaid under broad federal rules. State variability in eligibility and covered services, and how those services are reimbursed and delivered, is the rule rather than the exception. In the federal budget, Medicaid is an entitlement program that constitutes a large share of mandatory spending. Federal Medicaid spending is open-ended, with total outlays dependent on the spending levels of state Medicaid programs. SCHIP is authorized under Title XXI of the Social Security Act. In general, this program allows states to cover targeted low-income children with no health insurance in families with income that is above Medicaid eligibility levels. As of July 2006, the highest upper-income eligibility limit under SCHIP had reached 350% of the federal poverty level (FPL) in one state.
