The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a multilateral organization founded in 1967 to promote regional dialogue during the Cold War era. It has grown into a significant regional forum, representing a strategically and economically important region that includes some of the world's most critical sea lanes. ASEAN's primary goal is to increase multilateral dialogue and cooperation among its members. The organization has expanded to include underdeveloped nations like Laos, Cambodia, and Burma, which have created a wide range of interests within the group. ASEAN's symbolic commitment to "showing up" more frequently and at higher levels has helped improve its relationship with the United States. The organization has also taken steps to enhance its capacity to work with multilateral organizations, particularly ASEAN, to cooperate on issues of mutual interest.

The text discusses the state sponsors of terrorism list, which is mandated under Section 6(j) of the Export Administration Act of 1979. It mentions that Cuba has remained on the list since 1982 and that there are four other countries on the listIran, Syria, Sudan, and North Korea. The text also notes that the Administration's rationale for keeping Cuba on the list is based on strong anti-American statements made by Fidel Castro and other Cuban officials, while critics argue that Cuba's history of supporting revolutionary movements and governments in Latin America and Africa is a holdover of the Cold War. The text concludes by suggesting that there should be a tiered approach with sanctions calibrated to the degree of support for terrorism, while others believe that any level of support for terrorism is unacceptable and must be met with strong sanctions.

The AMT, a tax alternative, provides a broader tax base than the regular tax. It includes various provisions, such as not only business provisions but also certain itemized deductions, the standard deduction, and personal exemptions. After an exemption of $45,000 for joint returns and $33,750 for single returns, the first $175,000 is taxed at 26% and the remainder at 28%. Exemptions are phased out. The AMT base is broader than the regular tax base, but there are many provisions that are not included in its base, notably the benefits of lower capital gains tax rates and the exclusion for tax exempt bonds. The AMT exemptions are not indexed to inflation. The AMT tax liability is higher than the regular tax liability. The AMT is a growing tax alternative, and its growth is expected to increase the number of taxpayers covered and revenue cost. The AMT will become increasingly important in the years to come, and any tax cut that reduces regular tax liabilities and does not also alter the AMT will interact with the AMT in two ways: it will increase the number of taxpayers on the AMT and the number affected by the credit limit, and it will cause some or all of the tax cut not to be received by certain families.

The Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies (THUD) Appropriations Subcommittees in the House and Senate are tasked with drafting bills to provide annual appropriations for the Department of Transportation (DOT), the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), and six small related agencies. The THUD appropriations bill generally funds DOT. The department is primarily a grant-making and regulatory organization. Its programs are organized roughly by mode of transportation, providing grants to state and local government agencies to support the construction of highways, transit, airport, and intercity passenger rail infrastructure, while overseeing safety in all modes of transportation. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is exceptional among DOT's large sub-agencies in that the largest portion of its budget is not for grants but for operating the U.S. air traffic control system. In support of that task, it employs over 80% of DOT's total workforce, roughly 46,000 of DOT's approximately 56,000 employees. The Surface Transportation Board, formerly an agency of DOT, was made independent of DOT in 2015 legislation, and now appears in Title III of the THUD bill.

The United States and India have established a global partnership through increased cooperation on economic issues, energy and environment, democracy and development, non-proliferation and security, and high-technology and space. The U.S. policy is to isolate Iran and ensure its nuclear program is used for purely civilian purposes. India-Iran relations have traditionally been positive and, in January 2003, the two countries launched a "strategic partnership" with the signing of the "New Delhi Declaration" and seven other substantive agreements. Indian leaders regularly speak of "civilizational ties" between the two countries, a reference to the interactions of Persian and Indus Valley civilizations over a period of millennia. As U.S. relations with India grow deeper and more expansive in the new century, some in Washington believe that New Delhi's friendship with Tehran could become a significant obstacle to further development of U.S.-India ties. However, India-Iran relations have not evolved into a strategic alliance and are unlikely to derail the further development of a U.S.-India global partnership.

The United States has proposed new import restrictions on milk protein concentrates (MPCs), which are derived from raw milk and used in various food products, animal feed, and industrial products. Advocates argue that these restrictions would prevent unlimited importation of milk protein, which would encourage the use of domestically produced protein and raise milk prices for dairy farmers. Opponents counter that these restrictions would increase costs and result in higher retail food prices.

In October 2000, a coalition of democratic parties defeated Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic in presidential elections, overturning a regime that had plunged the country into bloody conflicts in the region, economic decline, and international isolation in the 1990s. Serbia has held largely free and fair elections, according to international observers. A new constitution adopted in 2006 marked an improvement over the earlier, Socialist-era one. However, the global economic crisis dealt a setback to Serbia's economy. Organized crime and high-level corruption remain very serious problems. Serbia has set integration in the European Union as its key foreign policy goal, but its prospects have been clouded by concerns of some EU countries that it has not done enough to normalize relations with its former Kosovo province, which declared independence in 2008. U.S.-Serbian relations, although positive in many respects, have also been negatively affected by the leading role played by the United States in promoting Kosovo's independence. Serbia's most recent parliamentary, presidential, and local elections were held on May 6, 2012. In the parliamentary vote, a coalition of parties led by the nationalist Serbian Progressive Party (SNS) won 73 seats in the 250-seat Serbian parliament. A pro-EU coalition led by the Democratic Party (DS) won 68 seats. In the biggest surprise of the vote, a coalition led by the Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS) won 45 seats, significantly more than expected. The strongly nationalist Democratic Party of Serbia (DSS) won 20 seats, as did a coalition led by the Liberal Democratic Party, which favors a less nationalist approach than the DS. The United Regions of Serbia group won 16 seats. Most of the remaining seats were won by representatives of national minorities. In the presidential election, outgoing President Tadic of the DS faced Tomislav Nikolic from the SNS, as well as candidates from smaller parties. Tadic took first place with 26.7% of the vote. Nikolic came in a close second with 25.5%. The other candidates trailed far behind. As no candidate received a majority, a runoff election was held between Tadic and Nikolic on May 20. In a result that surprised almost all observers, Nikolic defeated Tadic, winning 49.55% to Tadic's 47.3%. Voter turnout was 46.3

The Supreme Court in October 2012 decided four search and seizure cases involving dogs sniffing at the front door of suspected marijuana grow houses. The Court held that a dog sniff at the front door of a suspected marijuana grow house by a trained narcotics-detection dog is a Fourth Amendment search requiring probable cause. The Court also held that a dog sniff conducted during a concededly lawful traffic stop that reveals no information other than the location of a substance that no individual has any right to possess does not violate the Fourth Amendment. The Court's decision in Jardines, Harris, and Bailey involved the question of whether a trained narcotics-detection dog's sniff at the front door of a suspected marijuana grow house is a Fourth Amendment search requiring probable cause. The Court's decision in Caballes and Jardines was perhaps not surprising in light of its earlier decision in Harris. The Court's decision in Jardines was perhaps not surprising in light of its earlier decision in Harris.

The Federal Energy Administration (OE) supports the development of advanced energy storage technologies, including batteries, pumped hydro, flywheels, and energy storage systems. OE's mission is to modernize the electric power system and enhance grid resilience, while coordinating with industry to mitigate risks and improve system flexibility. The agency's cross-cutting programs include grid modernization, cybersecurity, and energy assurance planning.

The Commemorative Works Act (CWA) of 1986 established a 24-step process for the creation of commemorative works in the District of Columbia. The process involved the National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission, the U.S. Commission of Fine Arts, the National Capital Planning Commission, the District of Columbia Historic Preservation Office, and sometimes the American Battle Monuments Commission. Each entity was responsible for providing guidance and approval at multiple steps of the monument and memorial creation process. The CWA also provided additional subjects, such as viaducts, subways, major thoroughfares, monuments and memorials, public reservations, or property such as airports, parking areas, institutions, open spaces, public utilities, and surveys for transportation. The NCPC also operates under the authority of other laws for planning within the National Capital Region.

The Senate Finance Committee approved a bill, S. 1796, on October 13, 2009, which would reform health insurance in the United States. The bill would require insurers not to exclude potential enrollees or charge premiums based on pre-existing health conditions, and would require insurers to provide coverage on a guaranteed issue and guaranteed renewal basis. It would also require insurers to provide coverage for essential benefits and to charge the same premium regardless of whether the plan is purchased through an exchange (described below), the offeror, or an insurance agent. The bill would require all new health benefits plans offered in the individual and small group markets to be qualified health benefit plans that meet the insurance rating reforms and essential benefits package requirements specified in the bill.

In an effort to expand health coverage, 35 states have established high risk health insurance pools. These programs target individuals who cannot obtain or afford health insurance in the private market, primarily due to preexisting health conditions. High risk pools (HRPs) generally cover people who have sought health coverage in the individual (nongroup) market, but have been denied coverage, received quotes from insurers that are higher than the premiums offered by the high risk pools, or received offers from insurers that permanently exclude coverage of preexisting health conditions. Many states also use their high risk pools to comply with the portability and guaranteed availability provisions of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA, P.L. 104-191 ). For eligible individuals moving from the group to nongroup market, HIPAA requires state-licensed health insurers to make coverage available to such individuals, and prohibits exclusion of coverage for preexisting conditions. To enforce these rules, states are given a choice. They may either enforce the HIPAA individual market guarantees ("federal fallback"), or establish an "acceptable alternative state mechanism," such as a high risk health insurance pool. In general, state high risk pools tend to enroll a small percentage of the uninsured. For example, approximately 200,000 individuals were enrolled in the 34 high risk pools in operation in 2008. In contrast, the Government Accountability Office (GAO) estimated that nearly 4 million additional persons were potentially eligible for enrollment. However, such limited enrollment reflects, in part, the narrow focus of these pools: individuals with preexisting health conditions, who do not have access to public or group health insurance, and seek coverage in the private, non-group market.

The Civil Reserve Air Fleet (CRAF) program was created by President Truman in 1951 to support DOD airlift needs during emergencies when the need for airlift exceeds the capacity of DOD's organic airlift fleet.

The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is an agency in the U.S. Department of Commerce (DOC) that serves as the executive branch's principal advisory office on domestic and international telecommunications and information technology policies. The NTIA frequently works with other executive branch agencies to develop and present the Administration's position on key policy matters. It represents the executive branch in both domestic and international telecommunications and information policy activities. The NTIA acts as the representative of the Administration in both domestic and international spectrum management and spectrum access negotiations. It oversees the transfer of some radio frequencies from the federal domain to the commercial domain, and administers grants programs, including the Broadband Technology Opportunities Program (BTOP) and the Public Safety Interoperable Communications (PSIC) grant program. The NTIA leads and participates in interagency efforts to develop Internet policy, and supports the Office of Telecommunications and Information Applications (OTIA) and the Institute for Telecommunication Sciences (ITS).

The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (P.L. 109-58) was enacted in 2005, which was the first omnibus energy legislation enacted in more than a decade. The act aimed to improve reliability of the U.S. bulk power system by giving FERC jurisdiction over activities that are required to support reliability. The act also provided for the creation of a FERC-certified ERO to improve reliability as restructuring of the U.S. bulk power system proceeds. The act also provided for the creation of a regional advisory body if requested by at least two-thirds of the states within a region that have more than half of their electric load served within that region.

The Robinson-Patman Act, enacted in 1936, was created to create and maintain a market atmosphere in which small business could compete effectively, at least in the purchase of commodities, with its larger rivals. The act prohibits sellers in interstate commerce from charging different purchasers different prices for goods of "like grade and quality," where either or any of the purchases involved in such discrimination are in commerce, where such commodities are sold for use, consumption, or sale within the United States. The act applies only to the sale of goods (i.e., it does not apply to the sale of services) and only where each sale is of goods purchased for resale within the United States (i.e., it does not prohibit price differentials between goods sold for resale within the United States and those sold for export). The Robinson-Patman Act has been less than enthusiastically viewed by the Department of Justice, which believes that the act is not beneficial to consumers.

The text discusses the potential limits on Congress's authority to restrict the executive branch's enforcement discretion, particularly in the criminal and administrative contexts. It outlines the Supreme Court's precedent regarding the separation of powers and executive branch enforcement power. The text also mentions the potential for Congress to use its legislative powers to encourage the executive branch to enforce laws in a manner reflective of Congress's will, such as setting enforcement priorities or considering certain factors in the decision to initiate an enforcement action.

The text discusses the evolution of the U.S. poverty measure from the "official" measure to the Research Supplemental Poverty Measure (RSPM), which includes additional income and expenditure elements. It highlights the SPM's potential to improve understanding of the nature and circumstances of economically and socially vulnerable populations, offering insights into the economic vulnerability of the elderly and the impact of medical expenses on poverty among the aged.

The text discusses the U.S. farm policy, which is subject to intense scrutiny by the WTO due to its potential to diminish the breadth or impede the success of future multilateral negotiations. The U.S. farm bill, which was renewed every five or six years, includes provisions for classifying and counting domestic support programs, with four de minimis exclusions for amber box programs. The text also highlights the potential for trade-distorting support to spill over into international markets, and the need for domestic farm programs to comply with WTO rules.

The text discusses the history and current status of the campus-based financial aid programs authorized under Title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. It outlines the differences between the campus-based programs and other federal student aid programs, such as the Pell Grant and Direct Loan programs. The text also discusses the potential for reforming the campus-based programs to better serve a distinctive purpose and whether the current allocation procedures are optimal.

The text discusses the development and implementation of missing adult alert systems in 11 states across the United States. It highlights the differences in target populations, administrative procedures, and outcomes for different states. The report provides detailed information on the activation process, criteria for activating alerts, and the challenges faced by states in implementing these systems. It also discusses the potential role of the federal government in developing and coordinating missing adult alert systems, including the possibility of creating a uniform network of state alert systems and providing training and technical assistance to states.

The text provides a detailed comparison of the annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2017, highlighting the differences between the enacted FY2016 and FY2017 appropriations, the Obama Administration's FY2017 budget request, the Donald J. Trump Administration's requests for additional funding, and the appropriations measures developed in response. It also identifies additional informational resources, reports, and products on DHS appropriations that provide context for the discussion, and lists CRS policy experts who can provide assistance with specific topics.

The September 11, 2001, attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon have highlighted the vulnerability of many critical infrastructure systems, including water supply and water quality infrastructure. The report provides an overview of the large and diverse sector, describing security-related actions by the government and private sector since 9/11, and discussing additional policy issues and responses, including congressional interest. The potential for terrorism is not new, and the events of September 11, 2001, have changed the focus of water infrastructure security. The report presents a comprehensive overview of water infrastructure security, including vulnerability assessments, physical security enhancements, and the need for coordinated efforts between federal agencies and private sector stakeholders.

The Federal government has reauthorized and amended the Perkins Act, which authorizes funding for vocational and technical education programs. The act retains technical changes, but also adds new provisions for accountability and sanctions.

The text discusses the major provisions of the federal estate, gift, and generation-skipping transfer taxes as they apply to transfers in 2014. The enactment of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 phased out the estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes over a 10-year period, leaving the gift tax as the only federal transfer tax in 2010. The Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010 temporarily (through the end of 2012) reinstated the estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes with lower top rates and larger exemptions and reunified the estate and gift taxes. The American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012 permanently extended the estate tax rules enacted by the 2010 Act except for the top tax rate, which increased from 35% to 40%. The federal estate and gift taxes are unified as they utilize the same rate structure.

Border and Transportation Security (BTS) is a complex challenge that requires a layered approach to achieve better border and transportation security. The current programs and policies in place, however, reflect some layering. The framework highlighted in this report highlights the purposeful overlapping of programs and policies to attain BTS. Efforts to push the border outwards are aimed at preempting potential attacks and preventing individuals who are trying to surreptitiously enter the United States. The various preinspections and advance manifest rules were developed with this in mind. If someone, however, is able to penetrate the first layer of security, efforts to harden the border are put to the test. The use of biometric identifiers in travel documents and smart containers for the shipment of goods are both examples of how technology is being used to harden the border. The use of intelligence and engaging other actors such as state and local law enforcement and our foreign neighbors are other cumulative measures that have been taken to attain better BTS.

Cabo Verde, a small island nation in West Africa, has a long history of ties with the United States. It is a transshipment point for Latin American cocaine destined for Europe, and its location has made it a key refueling stopover for trans-Atlantic air traffic between Africa and the United States. Cabo Verde has a small population and is considered a lower-middle-income economy, with a per capita GNI of $3,280. It is a member of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and has a small national military. Cabo Verde is a participant in the Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC) development assistance program, and it has received limited U.S. development assistance. It is eligible for African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA) tariff preferences, but its exports under AGOA have generally been paltry. Cabo Verde has received limited assistance under the West Africa Regional Security Initiative (WARSI), and it has hosted multinational military exercises.

The text discusses the growing relationship between the United States and New Zealand, which has been characterized by a close security partnership and a return to close defense cooperation. It highlights the importance of shared values and the need for continued understanding and cooperation between the two nations, particularly in the context of the Asia Pacific region.

The U.S. Constitution establishes two methods by which Presidents may appoint officers of the United States: either with the advice and consent of the Senate, or unilaterally "during the Recess of the Senate." These two constitutional provisions have long served as sources of political tension between Presidents and Congresses. The January 4 appointments of Richard Cordray and Sharon Block, and Terrence F. Flynn, to the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (CFPB) and National Labor Relations Board (NLRB), respectively, raise significant constitutional questions. The Recess Appointments Clause authorizes the President to fill up all Vacancies that may happen during the Recess of the Senate, but the Senate's pro forma sessions may prevent a President from making recess appointments. The President's appointments of Cordray, Flynn, Block, and Griffin Jr. during a three-day recess between pro forma sessions raises a number of significant legal questions that may lead to judicial challenge. However, prior to assessing the merits of any challenge, a reviewing court would first consider a number of preliminary questions of justiciability, including whether the plaintiffs who have brought the claim have standing and whether the asserted claims present matters appropriately resolved by a court. An extended preliminary discussion of these justiciability questions is necessary because they may have relevance to many of the underlying legal questions posed by the Recess Appointments Clause, the President's recent actions thereunder, and the operation of the statutory authorities exercised by the recess appointees in this case.

The text discusses the implementation and expansion of expedited removal procedures under the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA) following the passage of IIRIRA in 1996. It outlines the initial implementation of the new expedited removal statute for arriving aliens, including those who arrived by sea and had not been admitted or paroled. The text also describes the expansion of expedited removal to aliens who arrived in the United States by sea, including those who had not been physically present in the United States for at least two years.

The legal framework for congressional redistricting involves constitutional and federal statutory requirements, including the standard for equality of population among districts, the Voting Rights Act (VRA), and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause. Supreme Court case law interprets these requirements, with the 2015 ruling in Arizona State Legislature v. Arizona Independent Redistricting Commission upholding an Arizona constitutional provision that established an independent commission for drawing congressional districts.

The text discusses the high cost of wildfire management and the effects of increased costs on other agency management programs, including fuel reduction efforts and post-fire rehabilitation. It also highlights the need for better cost control and accountability in wildfire suppression, with the possibility of integrating wildfire management into land and resource planning and budgeting.

Across the United States, about 27.5% of state and local government employees work in positions that are not covered by Social Security. Coverage rates vary considerably across states, as shown in Table 1. In 26 states, 90% or more of state and local government employees work in positions covered by Social Security. In three states, more than 95% of state and local government employees are covered by Social Security: Arizona (95.3%), New York (96.7%), and Vermont (97.9%). In two states, fewer than 5% of state and local government employees work in positions covered by Social Security: Massachusetts (4.1%) and Ohio (2.5%). States in which less than half of state and local government employees are in positions covered by Social Security include California (43.6%), Colorado (29.1%), Louisiana (27.9%), Nevada (17.6%), and Texas (47.9%). The 1935 Social Security Act did not extend Social Security coverage to state and local government workers. In 1950, Congress added Section 218 to the Social Security Act to allow all 50 states, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands to elect Social Security coverage for certain state and local government employees. In 1954, Congress extended voluntary coverage to employees who were already covered by pension plans, effective starting in 1955, if a majority of employees who were members of a pension system voted in favor of Social Security coverage. The Bipartisan Policy Center's Debt Reduction Task Force, co-chaired by former Senator Pete Domenici and Dr. Alice Rivlin, recommended that all newly hired state and local government employees be covered under the Social Security system, beginning in 2020, to increase the universality of the program. In addition, the Bipartisan Policy Center recommended that state and local pension plans be required to share data with SSA until the transition is complete. The Bipartisan Policy Center noted that implementation should be delayed until 2020 to give state and local governments time to "shore up and reform their pension systems" pointing to the poor fiscal condition of state and local governments and the underfunding of public employee pensions.

The Trade Adjustment Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2015 (TAARA, Title IV of P.L. 114-27) reauthorized TAA, which provides readjustment assistance to workers who have lost their jobs due to foreign competition or offshoring. The eligibility and benefit provisions of TAARA apply to all workers certified for TAA after the law's enactment. The law also had retroactivity provisions and, in some cases, workers who were parts of groups certified prior to the 2015 reauthorization may be covered under the TAARA provisions. TAA was jointly administered by the U.S. Department of Labor (DOL) and cooperating state agencies. DOL makes group eligibility determinations, allocates funds to cooperating state agencies, and oversees grantees. Individual benefits are provided through state workforce systems and state unemployment insurance systems. TAA is funded by mandatory appropriations. Typically, Congress appropriates a single sum that supports all TAA activities. DOL then allocates these funds to various program activities. Under TAARA, funding for training and reemployment services is capped at $450 million per year. These funds are allotted to the states via a grant allocation formula that considers past and anticipated program usage. States may expend training and reemployment service funds in the year of allotment or in either of the next two fiscal years. Training subsidies are states' primary expenditures out of their reemployment services funding. TAA is a direct spending (also referred to as "mandatory") program and subject to sequestration under the Budget Control Act of 2011, as amended. For FY2018, the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) determined that the reduction for nonexempt, nondefense spending would be 6.6%. Sequester levels in subsequent years will be determined by OMB. In FY2018, Congress appropriated $790 million for the TAA for Workers programs. Of this amount, $450 million was for training and reemployment services and the remaining $340 million was for income support and wage insurance. The entire $790 million appropriation was subject to 6.6% sequestration ($52.14 million). DOL opted to apply the entirety of the sequestration to the training and reemployment services funding, reducing the funding for training and reemployment services from $450 million to $397.86 million and leaving the $340

The Federal Employee Dental and Vision Benefits Enhancement Act of 2004 established the Federal Employees Dental and Vision Insurance Program (FEDVIP) to provide supplemental dental and vision benefits to federal employees, Members of Congress, annuitants, and dependents. The program was available on December 31, 2006, and enrollees are responsible for 100% of the premiums. Employees who are eligible to enroll in the FEHB program may also enroll in FEDVIP. FEDVIP plans are available in four nationwide dental plans and three additional dental plans that are only available regionally. The premiums vary by plan, by whether the enrollment includes other family members, and by residency (for dental plans only). The benefits provided by these plans include Class A, Class B, and Class C services, with premiums varying by geographic area.

The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 provided $17.15 billion in supplemental FY2009 discretionary appropriations for biomedical research, public health, and other health-related programs within the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).

The Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act (LMR) requires meat packers to report prices and other information on purchases of cattle, hogs, lamb, boxed beef, wholesale pork, and lamb carcasses and boxed lamb to the U. S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). The act was reauthorized through September 30, 2020, and extended until September 30, 2025.

The text discusses the potential consequences of a sitting United States Senator being indicted for or convicted of a felony offense, which does not affect their status or service in Congress. It also mentions that internal party rules in the Senate may affect a Senator's leadership and committee positions, but no specific Rule of the Senate exists for this situation.

The text discusses the current state of forestry assistance programs administered by the U.S. Forest Service (FS). It provides a brief overview of the program's purpose, types of activities funded, eligibility requirements, authorized program duration and funding level, and requested and enacted program appropriations. The text also highlights the decline in forestry assistance programs over the past 15 years, with some programs being repealed or unfunded by Congress.

Transnational organized crime groups, including drugs, humans, guns, wildlife, gems, and timber, are flourishing in Burma, trafficking contraband that includes drugs, humans, guns, wildlife, gems, and timber. The country's extra-legal economy, both black market and illicit border trade, is large and complex, with many forms of contraband trafficking. The country's border regions share many features of ungoverned spaces, with physical terrain that is difficult to control. The 110th Congress has been active in U.S. policy toward Burma, including on issues related to transnational crime. The 111th Congress may choose to continue its interest in oversight of U.S. policy toward Burma, including the country's role in criminal activity.

The ACA, a federal health insurance program, has provided significant funding to support various programs and initiatives, including community health centers, national health service corps, and health workforce demonstration programs.

The text discusses the increasing presence of foreign students in graduate science and engineering programs and the scientific workforce in the United States. It highlights the concerns of the scientific community, arguing for ceilings on admissions for immigrants, and maintains that foreign students use U.S. graduate education programs as stepping stones to immigration. The report also mentions that the number of foreign-born students increased by 8.0% in 2008-2009, the largest recorded increase since 1980. The report also notes that foreign students on temporary resident visas earned 32.0% of the doctorates in the sciences and 58.6% of the doctorates in engineering.

The text discusses the FY2018 EERE budget request and the proposed EERE funding levels and priorities in the related E&W appropriations bills. It highlights that the Administration's request for EERE programs would focus on "early-stage R&D" and would result in a decrease of nearly 70% for EERE programs. The text also mentions that both H.R. 3219 and S. 1609 would provide appropriations for FY2018 above the Administration's request of $184 million for sustainable transportation.

Cryptocurrencies, such as Bitcoin, are digital money that operates as a payment system in an electronic payment system. They are decentralized and use public ledgers to validate transactions. While they have the potential to facilitate transactions and provide anonymity, they are still limited in their ability to serve as a medium of exchange, unit of account, and store of value. Cryptocurrencies face challenges in widespread adoption, including regulatory hurdles, lack of trust, and the need for new intermediaries. Their potential benefits are debated, with proponents arguing they will increase economic efficiency and privacy, while skeptics argue they will not be a widely used form of money.

The Bankruptcy Code's proposed amendments to section 1113 of the Bankruptcy Code would limit the court's discretion to approve rejection of CBA proposals and would require labor groups to have a greater role in determining the feasibility of reorganization.

The report discusses appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2016, focusing on the components of DHS including the Office of the Secretary, Executive Management, Office of the Under Secretary for Management, DHS headquarters consolidation project, Office of the Chief Financial Officer, Office of the Chief Information Officer, Analysis and Operations, and the Office of Inspector General. The report provides an overview of the Administration's FY2016 request for Departmental Management and Operations, the appropriations proposed by Congress, and the enacted amounts. It highlights the impact of these appropriations on the department's management activities, including the consolidation of headquarters, and the oversight of DHS operations.

The text discusses the distinction between net job loss and gross job loss, which are both important macroeconomic problems. It explains that gross job loss is the result of greater gross job loss than gross job gains, while net job loss is the result of net job loss than net job gains. The text also mentions that trade, trade deficits, offshore outsourcing, overseas investment, and economic restructuring all cause gross job loss, but none typically cause net job loss. It concludes that public policies to protect workers against the risks posed by gross job loss can be justified on both social and economic grounds.

In 2012, Abe's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) led Japan's prime ministerial election, and Abe was re-elected as prime minister. Abe's LDP government implemented a series of economic reforms, including the expansion of the labor market, the privatization of state-owned enterprises, and the deregulation of the financial sector. These reforms were aimed at boosting economic growth and reducing inflation. The Abe administration also implemented measures to improve the competitiveness of Japan's economy, including the expansion of the manufacturing sector and the promotion of exports. The government's efforts to boost economic growth were met with criticism from some domestic and international observers, who argued that the reforms were not sufficient to address the country's economic challenges.

The text discusses the challenges faced by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in providing adequate health care to noncitizens detained by ICE. It highlights the inadequacies in the Detention Standards, the lack of oversight, and the difficulties in providing medical care to detainees. The report also mentions the need for improved medical care for detainees and the potential for increased funding for detainee health care.

The text discusses the creation of the Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC) by the United States to manage foreign aid programs. It outlines the key elements of the MCC, including its establishment by the Administration, the establishment of a Board of Directors, and the creation of a CEO. The text also discusses the potential challenges and issues that may arise with the MCC, such as the need for flexibility in resource allocation and the potential for tradeoffs between different aid programs.

The 112th Congress is considering an omnibus farm bill that will establish the direction of agricultural policy for the next several years. The Senate Agriculture Committee approved its version of the 2012 omnibus farm bill on April 26, 2012 (Agriculture Reform, Food and Jobs Act of 2012), and officially filed the measure, S. 3240, on May 24, 2012. After the bill was filed, more than 300 amendments were proposed for consideration on the Senate floor. By mid-June, an agreement was reached to limit the debate to 77 of the proposed amendments, of which 45 were adopted between June 19 and June 21. The full Senate approved S. 3240, as amended, by a vote of 64-35 on June 21. The House Agriculture Committee completed markup of its version of the farm bill (H.R. 6083), on July 11, 2012, and approved the amended measure by a 35-11 vote. Nearly 100 amendments were offered for committee consideration, of which nearly half were adopted by the committee. The House bill was officially filed and reported by the committee on September 13, 2012. Within their 12 titles, the five-year House and Senate farm bills would reshape the structure of farm commodity support, expand crop insurance coverage, consolidate conservation programs, revise the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (formerly food stamps), and extend authority to appropriate funds for many U. S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) discretionary programs through FY2017.

The text discusses the current financing system for inland waterways in the United States, including the IWTF (Inland Waterways Trust Fund) and the fuel tax. It highlights the IWUB's proposal to increase the fuel tax rate, which would shift the cost-share responsibility from the federal government to the Corps. The report also proposes changes to the cost-sharing arrangements for inland waterways projects, including the IWUB's proposal to increase the involvement of the Corps in project delivery and to tie some projects to the General Revenue fund. The text also discusses the IWUB's proposal to increase the cost-share responsibility for some inland waterway investments, including the Olmsted Locks and Dam Project. The report notes that the IWTF is currently funded by the federal government, but the IWUB's proposal to increase the fuel tax rate would shift this responsibility to the Corps. The text concludes by discussing the IWUB's proposal to increase the cost-share responsibility for some inland waterway investments, including the Olmsted Locks and Dam Project.

Congress has historically used commemorative legislation to name federal buildings, post offices, postage stamps, monuments, memorials, and other public works. Legislation requiring legislation to name a post office or other federal building in honor or in memory of locally esteemed individuals, deceased elected officials, fallen military personnel, and celebrities is a common practice. Commemorative legislation can be used to name post offices for persons, designating facilities after individuals, and establishing commemorative observances, such as the National Pearl Harbor Remembrance Day. The House and Senate have adopted rules to prevent commemorative legislation from including a remembrance, celebration, or recognition for any purpose through the designation of a specified period of time.

The text discusses the FY2013 budget request for selected COMPETES 2010 provisions, including the doubling path policy for the NSF, NIST core laboratories, and the DOE Office of Science. It highlights the differences between FY2012 and FY2013 funding levels for these accounts, including the Administration's FY2013 request for increased funding for the doubling path accounts. The text also notes that the FY2013 budget request for the DOE Office of Science included no funding for SCGF, while the FY2012 request for the Fusion Energy Sciences "Other" activity was $11.9 million.

The 2008 amendments to the Lacey Act have been controversial, with some arguing for changes through regulations while others contend for changes through law. Some contend that changes should be made through regulations, while others argue for changes through law. Some propose removing violations of foreign laws from the Lacey Act, while others contend that this would lead to additional changes in the law that are not supported by stakeholders.
The 2002 Farm Security and Rural Investment Act (FSRIA) provides new long-term counter-cyclical support for grains and cotton, replacing deficiency payments with fixed, "direct payments" to farmers.

The study demonstrates that counter-current dialysis using a standard clinical cvvh filter and under clinical conditions removes endothelial cells (huvec passage 46; clonetics, walkersville, md) from a modelled patient's circulation. The data presented here demonstrate that counter-current dialysis using a standard clinical cvvh filter and under clinical conditions removes endothelial cells from a modelled patient's circulation. The study also shows that the observed emp clearance is likely a saturable phenomenon, which would explain the relatively constant emp concentration from 40 to 70 minutes and low dialysate emp levels. The relative volume of human circulation ( ~5 l ) to cvvh circuit ( ~200 ml ) is much higher in the clinical condition as compared to our model ( 300 and 170 ml , respectively ). While this would not affect a steady state of dialysis, a saturable filter emp - binding would be required to achieve a lower steady state emp concentration. The low dialysate emp level and plateauing circulation emp level beyond 40 minutes suggest that emp sequestration occurs within the cvvh filter or tubing and that this is a saturable phenomenon. Frequent changing of the cvvh filter is a logical step that may overcome this limitation. Additionally, more efficient and selective emps clearance can be realized by conjugating endothelium-specific antibodies to commercially available specialty cvvh filters (aethlon adapt). This approach would provide more selective binding sites and higher affinity for circulating emps. By combining a selective filter with convection and pressure gradients, emp clearance could likely be substantially prolonged. Clinical data generally support the protective role of cvvh in ali management. The text discusses the development of a post-coupling methodology to attach biological targeting ligands to nanoparticles, specifically rgd peptides and rge control peptides. The association between diabetes and cancer has been a subject of debate for over a century. The length of this debate suggests that any such associations are relatively weak, and most practicing diabetologists do not view cancer as a specific, diabetes-associated risk. The role of insulin in managing type 2 diabetes and its potential to promote cancer growth is also discussed. The epidemiologic studies that initially sparked the debate have been reviewed, and the results suggest that glargine, a newer form of insulin, may be associated with increased cancer risk. The meta-analysis comparing cancer risk associated with another new, long-acting insulin, insulin detemir, versus nph and glargine, is also discussed.

Tibial adamantinoma is a rare, slow-growing primary bone tumor that presents with localized regional nodal metastases. The tumor is associated with osteofibrous / fibrous dysplasia and is considered a spectrum of disease with evidence of progression from osteofibrous / fibrous dysplasia to adamantinoma in some cases. It can occur at any age but is most commonly localized in the tibial diaphysis. The tumor is divided into two main groups based on its histology and biological behavior. It can be associated with osteofibrous / fibrous dysplasia and is considered a spectrum of disease with evidence of progression from osteofibrous / fibrous dysplasia to adamantinoma in some cases. It can present at any age but is mostly in the second to fourth decade.

For patients with synchronous colorectal liver metastases, simultaneous resection is considered the best treatment with reported 5-year survival rates between 23% and 37%. However, staged resections with initial operation for the primary lesion followed by hepatectomy for liver metastasis are also considered. The morbidity rate after simultaneous resection of primary and liver tumors was high because of greater surgical stress and a longer operation time than for single organ surgery. The efficacy of staged resections and patients who could benefit from this strategy are unknown.

The study aimed to validate two scores for assessing inhaler technique errors in asthma patients. The second score, based on the use of inhaled or oral corticosteroids, quantified the errors made during the use of corticosteroids. The text discusses the discovery and characterization of enterocin s37, a bacteriocin produced by e. faecalis recently isolated from chicken feces. Enterocin s37 is characterized as a class iia bacteriocin with a molecular weight of <10 kDa, sensitivity to proteases, and stability at different pH and temperatures. It is found to increase activity several folds during purification, reaching 1,557.17 au g. Enterocin s37 alone did not affect the growth of the resistant variant of l. monocytogenes egde, but the combination of enterocin s37/k channel modulators significantly impacted the growth of the resistant strain. The study conducted in compliance with international guidelines, including the Helsinki Declaration, the European Union Clinical Trials Directive, and local regulatory requirements, evaluated the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of intrathecal dosing of nusinersen in children with spinal muscular atrophy. The study included 73 lumbar punctures performed in 13 children, 15 with spinal muscular atrophy type 2 and 13 with spinal muscular atrophy type 3. The majority of lumbar punctures were carried out using either a 22- or 25-gauge needle, and nearly half were guided using fluoroscopy. The most common adverse events were headache, back pain, and post- lumbar puncture syndrome. The study demonstrated that using a 24-gauge needle or smaller in children with spinal muscular atrophy to perform lumbar puncture with lower incidence of complications, suggesting that using a 24-gauge or smaller needle would likely reduce the chance of adverse events.

The study explores the facilitators and barriers in clinical governance implementation in Iran. The study aimed to determine the epidemiological and clinical status of human hydatidosis in Khorasan Razavi Province during 2011-2014. The text discusses the first case of a ciliated hepatic foregut cyst (chfc) described by Friedrich in 1857. It outlines the characteristics of chfc, including its congenital origin, presence of four typical layers, and its relationship to other hepatic cysts. The paper reports the case of a 32-year-old woman with a 6-month history of right upper quadrant pain, diagnosed with a chfc. The cyst was found adherent to the liver, and a laparoscopic deroofing was planned. The cyst was identified as a ciliated foregut cyst of hepatic origin without evidence of epithelial dysplasia or invasive malignancy.

The text discusses the development and optimization of oral solid dosage forms for the delivery of clobazam, a drug used to treat epilepsy. It highlights the use of polymers such as ssg (disintegrant) and pva (film former) in the formulation of clobazam. The study involved three formulations, including a 2 cm strip, a 4 cm strip, and a 1 cm strip, each prepared using different polymer concentrations and film forming agents. The study also demonstrated that the optimized formulation was stable for at least 6 months, making it potentially useful for the treatment of epileptic attacks.

The review examined the methodological quality of outcome measures used in stroke self-management studies, highlighting inconsistencies in reporting and the lack of consensus on appropriate measures. It found that most studies did not report validity and reliability data, and that measures used in stroke self-management were not reflective of the process or outcomes of self-management. The study aimed to investigate the correlation between subjective measures of the Koos questionnaire and objective measures such as 6-minute walk test (6-mwt), age, height, weight, and BMI in knee osteoarthritis (OA) patients. The study examined the effects of a high-fat diet combined with short-term ovariectomy on the metabolic and inflammatory processes in rats. The source document discusses the effectiveness of embolization therapy in controlling massive hemoptysis, which is a common symptom in patients with respiratory diseases. Angiogenesis, the process by which existing blood vessels expand to form new blood vessels, is crucial for the growth of solid tumors. The inhibition of angiogenesis with drugs like bevacizumab and 2c3 has shown promise in treating breast cancer, reducing tumor volume and improving outcomes.

The source document discusses the prevalence and impact of vaginal atrophy (vva) in postmenopausal women, highlighting its common medical condition and the challenges in discussing symptoms with healthcare providers. The study aimed to estimate the prevalence of prenatal vitamin (fa) and multivitamin (mv) supplements among Danish pregnancy planners. The study was conducted using a prospective cohort design, involving 5383 pregnant women from 2007 to 2011. The results showed that 62% of the pregnant women in the study adhered to the Danish fa recommendation, while 11% used mv supplements. The study also found that women who had unplanned pregnancies were less likely to use fa supplements before pregnancy. The prevalence of fa and mv use was higher among pregnant women with higher education levels, higher income, and higher smoking rates. The study also found that women with a history of childbirth were more likely to use fa supplements. The study's findings suggest that women with a history of childbirth may be more likely to use fa supplements, which may be related to increased awareness about preconceptional fa guidelines.

The study evaluated lipid peroxidation parameters and total antioxidant capacity in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD) before and after surgery. The text discusses the effects of glaucoma, a neurodegenerative disease characterized by the loss of retinal ganglion cells and optic nerve atrophy. It highlights that multiple factors, including high intraocular pressure (IOP) and low cerebral spinal fluid pressure, are associated with glaucoma. The study found that mller cells not only support and nourish retinal neurons but also contribute to multiple pathological retinal diseases such as glaucoma. The role of endoscopic injection of dextranomer/hyaluronic acid copolymer (dx / ha) in treating pediatric vesicoureteral reflux (vur) has expanded as an alternative to open surgery. The technique has been FDA-approved since 2001 for grade 24 vur in single systems with no accompanying urological malformations in children above one year of age. The technique has been popularized with surgeons and parents alike. Reports of expanded use to patients of all ages and grades of vur even in the presence of duplication, ureterocele, or other lower tract anomalies are published worldwide. The initial success rate was quoted as 68% and is still mentioned on the current website. The original subureteric injection technique (sting) has evolved to the intraureteric injection technique introduced by the atlanta group. Using this hydrodistention-implantation technique (hit), the authors reported success rates of 89%. However, the reported worldwide success rates differ considerably (55%89% [7,8]). The radiographic success rate for patients and renal units after the first injection was 75% for both groups. The intraoperative cystogram was developed to detect occult vur in patients with recurrent urinary tract infections (utis) after a negative standard voiding cystogram. The detection of de novo vur in patients with preoperative unilateral refluxing vur was found intraoperatively in 27 ru (23% of 116 patients). The high-pressure intraoperative cystogram (group 1) was performed in 86 rus and the standard pic (group 2) in 91 rus. There was no statistically significant difference between groups 1 and 2 for the detection of de novo vur. The dx / ha deposits were seen in all cases. At 2 months, the intraoperative standard vcug detected 20 ru (23% of 116 patients) to be positive for vur in group 1 and 16 ru (18% of 116 patients) positive for vur in group 2. Overall, the grade of vur, age, gender, and amount of deflux injected did not influence the result. The endoscopic injection of dx / ha is an attractive management alternative for parents. When presenting the surgical options, all parents are enthusiastic about the minimal invasive nature of the procedure with low complication possibilities and fast recovery times

The accuracy of fetal pathology detection depends on the expertise of the sonographer and the limitations of the imaging technique. Onychomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the nails, characterized by nail discoloration, thickening, and defect. The most common pathogens are dermatophytes, yeasts, and nondermatophytic molds. Onychomycosis can extend to other nails and cause complications, especially in at-risk patients. The treatment of onychomycosis is difficult due to the predisposing factors not influenced by therapy. Tazarotene, a topical antifungal drug, is effective in reducing fungal growth and is used for the treatment of onychomycosis.

The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of endocardial pacing in patients not responding to conventional CRT. The authors found that endocardial pacing could improve clinical outcomes in patients with LV dyssynchrony, but the optimal position was not always reached in the tributaries of the coronary sinus. The study also highlighted the importance of lead location and the need for endocardial pacing opposite the coronary sinus to achieve better results. The study showed that a temporary acute haemodynamic study could be useful in non-responders to CRT, but the optimal cut-off value for LV dp / dtmax before improvement justifies intervention.

The autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) affects between 1 in every 500 and 1 in every 1000 individuals, with a prevalence of 0.0002% in the general population. The disease is characterized by the formation of cysts in the kidneys, leading to the development of kidney failure. The disease is more common in women with moderate or severe antenatal renal insufficiency, and it can progress to renal failure in up to 30% of patients. The disease is associated with a high risk of complications, including maternal hypertension, preeclampsia, anemia, and kidney and liver cysts. The disease is also associated with a high risk of end-stage renal disease during or shortly after pregnancy. The disease is managed with peritoneal dialysis, intravenous fluids, and anticoagulation.

The study analyzed the lactation curve parameters of milk yield and persistency traits in cows, including gamma type function. The gamma function was found to be the best model for predicting milk yield in cows, with approximately one third of lactation curves named as atypical. The gamma function was also reported to have a similar value in normal and mastitis cows, further supporting its accuracy in predicting milk yields in cows with mastitis. The gamma function was also reported to have a similar value in normal and mastitis cows during different parities, further supporting its accuracy in predicting milk yields in cows with mastitis.

The text discusses the use of different magnetic nanoparticles for localization of sentinel lymph nodes during breast cancer surgery. It highlights the importance of particle size and coating in determining the effectiveness of the magnetic nanoparticles. The 59 nm tracer, with its larger particle size and better particle size distribution, is currently the best performing magnetic nanoparticle tracer for breast cancer sentinel lymph node localization.

The study identified vaspin, a serine protease inhibitor, in visceral adipose tissue of rats with obesity and type 2 diabetes. Vaspin is expressed in skin, hypothalamus, pancreatic islets, and stomach. Vaspin levels are significantly higher in men with metabolic syndrome compared to those without the syndrome. The serum vaspin levels in diabetic patients with renal insufficiency are higher than those in subjects with normal glucose tolerance. The study found that serum vaspin levels are positively correlated with creatinine levels and are significantly reduced in Japanese chronic hemodialysis patients. The correlation between serum vaspin and adiponectin levels is also significant. The study suggests that vaspin levels may be useful for predicting cardiovascular events and patient survival in patients with obesity and type 2 diabetes.

The text discusses the use of surrogate variables to predict wound healing in advanced diabetic foot ulcers. It presents the results of a multicenter, double-blind, randomized clinical trial that tested the surrogate variables proposed for neuropathic dfus and explored the correlation between granulation tissue development and complete healing during follow-up for 1 year. The study found that several surrogate variables can be considered for the final outcome in advanced dfus, including ischemic, wagner grade 3 or 4, and median area > 20 cm. The study also suggests that the predictive property of percent area change, log healing rate, and ratio of log area can be extrapolated to more complicated, ischemic, larger, and wagner grade 3 or 4 ulcers. However, the cutoff points for classification were not the same, and the correct classification percent in the present series was < 70% with negative pvs < 60. The extrapolation of the cutoff points proposed in the present work has the limitation of the small sample size analyzed, so further research is needed.

The study compared the perioperative extent of surgical trauma and its postoperative impact on the abdominal wall after laparoscopic tapp mesh repair versus needlescopic surgery. The results showed that the ntapp procedure reduced immediate postoperative pain in wound regions, while the stapp procedure did not. The study also found that the ntapp procedure had comparable long-term results in hernia recurrence, abdominal wall mobility, and cosmetic satisfaction.

The study aimed to verify the correlation between nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry in the diagnosis of hyperplasia of the pharyngeal tonsils, highlighting their main contributions. The findings showed a regular and positive correlation between the two exams, but cephalometry underestimated the pharyngeal tonsil size in the nasopharynx.

The text discusses the incidence of ipsilateral breast tumor relapse (IBTR) in patients treated for breast cancer through breast conserving surgery, systemic adjuvant therapy, and radiation therapy. It emphasizes the importance of distinguishing between true local recurrence (tr) and new primary tumors (npt) to accurately assess the risk of recurrence. The text also highlights the need for genetic studies to differentiate between er-positive and er-negative breast cancer, as well as the importance of considering age, family history, and other risk factors in determining the optimal systemic therapy for IBTR.

The study evaluated the efficacy of intravitreal aflibercept treatment in patients with neovascular AMD, demonstrating a significant improvement in cs and a reduction in crt over 12 weeks. The study also found a positive correlation between improvement in cs and reduction in crt, suggesting that measurement of cs may provide a more complete understanding of the benefits of aflibercept on vision-related functional performance in patients with neovascular AMD.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by network vascular inflammation, demyelination, and axonal damage. It is a chronic, progressive condition affecting the central nervous system, causing severe cognitive and physical impairments. The c424c / a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene has been evaluated in an Iranian population, revealing that it is not associated with MS. The study suggests that other polymorphisms within the IL-25 gene may also play a role in MS pathogenesis, but the c424c / a polymorphism is not important. The study also indicates that using a large sample size may be better for understanding the roles of the c424c / a polymorphism in the pathogenesis of MS.

The study evaluated the entire aorta diameter, from the thoracic aorta to the abdomen aorta just above the iliac bifurcation, using axial images of non-contrast CT scans in a population with multiple risk factors for both coronary heart disease (CHD) and aortic aneurysm (AA). The study found that taa was associated with absence of dyslipidemia, while aaa was independently associated with presence of dyslipidemia. The results highlight the importance of understanding the relationship between taa and aaa, as they are both associated with high prevalence in elderly Korean males with multiple risk factors for CHD and AA. The study also found that taa was more prevalent in elderly Korean males with hypertension compared to those without hypertension, reinforcing the need for further research to clarify the relationship between taa and aaa.

The study aimed to investigate whether liquid-based surepath preparation for endometrial cytology test ( ect ) can maintain the three-dimensional structure of the endometrium. The study was performed from November 2011 to May 2014 at the obstetrics and gynecology department of Peking University First Hospital and was approved by the hospital ethics committee. The risk factors included age, intrinsically high estrogen, extrinsically high estrogen, high body mass index, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, family history of cancer, history of radiation and smoking, abnormal uterus bleeding, abnormal endometrium assessed by ultrasound, and postmenopausal vaginal bleeding. The study found that the sap-1 sampling device can provide more sufficient materials for cytology than d & c or hysteroscopic biopsy for histology. The current study comprised of 1514 patients with endometrial carcinoma risk factors underwent sap-1 sampling on an outpatient basis, and 375 of these women also underwent d & c or hysteroscopy. The characteristics of the patients included age distribution, menstrual status, and symptoms and signs. The results showed that the sap-1 sampling device can provide more adequate specimens than d & c or hysteroscopic biopsy for histology. The accuracy of detecting endometrial precursor and carcinoma was estimated at 91.7%, sensitivity at 73.6%, specificity at 94.9%, ppv at 71.9%, and npv at 95.3%.

Breast cancer remains a significant health concern worldwide, with nearly 1.7 million new cases reported in 2012. The highest incidence rates are in Europe and North America, with screening mammography associated with a 50% reduction in mortality rate. Despite controversy about mammogram screening, digital mammography (dm) remains the most commonly performed procedure for breast cancer detection. dm is less likely to be lost or damaged, has slightly higher sensitivity than sfm, and can help solve the problem of radiation exposure in tomosynthesis. The review highlights the potential benefits of using dm over sfm in reducing false positives and improving cancer detection.

The study demonstrates that diphenhydramine inhibits cough reflex sensitivity, which is a recognized antitussive in the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) OTC monograph. The study also shows that diphenhydramine has been shown to inhibit citric acid-induced cough in healthy volunteers, as well as to diminish pathological chronic cough relative to placebo. The study also shows that capsaicin cough challenge testing has become an important tool in clinical research, allowing for the accurate measurement of the effect of a pharmacological intervention on the sensitivity of the cough reflex.

The text discusses schwannomas, a rare type of intracranial tumor, which arise from the peripheral nervous system. The study compares the biomechanical properties of short-segment pedicle screws with and without intermediate screws at the fracture level for managing unstable burst fractures. The dream trial was a large, international, multicenter, double-blind, randomized controlled trial designed to determine whether ramipril and/or rosiglitazone could prevent or delay the development of type 2 diabetes in people with ifg or igt, metabolic states that indicate very high risk for eventual progression to diabetes. The trial included 5,269 participants with these disorders, recruited through screening OGTTs and followed for a median of 3 years. Participants were assessed at regular intervals to determine the occurrence of the primary outcome, which included new-onset diabetes or all-cause mortality. The primary outcome variable was change in -cell function over the course of follow-up. The study found that ramipril and/or rosiglitazone significantly reduced the risk of developing diabetes, while rosiglitazone improved measures of -cell function over time in people with ifg and/or igt. The results suggest that measures of change in -cell function in response to therapy are indexes of that therapy's ability to reduce the incidence of diabetes.

The text discusses the metabolic interactions between two strains of E. coli, where the strains are genetically engineered to interact. The authors extend the metabolic network analysis to identify synthetic genetic interactions, which are characterized by the exchange of metabolites between strains. They find that certain pairs of strains exhibit synergistic growth, where one strain benefits from the growth of another. The authors also identify a quantitative theoretical model that predicts the extent to which complex metabolic interactions emerge from the relatively simple topology of the biochemical reaction network. They use synthetic genetic interactions to infer properties of the metabolic network, such as the investment benefits of cooperative growth. The model also predicts that synthetic genetic interactions can be used to infer biochemical reaction rates through flux balance analysis. The authors conclude that synthetic genetic interactions can be used to identify epistatic or modular relationships among genes, and that synthetic genetic interactions can be applied to infer metabolic network stoichiometries through flux balance analysis.

The text describes a case of brook-spiegler syndrome (BSS), a rare genetic disorder characterized by the progressive formation of adnexal skin tumors in the scalp and face, mainly trichoepiteliomas, cylindromas, and spiradenomas. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the tumor suppressor gene cyld on chromosome 16q12q13. The study of cyld gene mutations in patients and their relatives can provide molecular diagnosis and genetic counselling. The low risk of malignancy and patients require long-term follow-up. The genetic study in the patient's daughter confirmed the association of the cyld mutation with BSS. The case supports the hypothesis that the germline mutation and variable presence of somatic mutation influence the final phenotype. The authors recommend a correct diagnosis and periodic follow-up of patients.

The study evaluated the mechanical properties, resorption profiles, and histological characteristics of phasix mesh and p4hb plug designs when utilized to bridge a surgical defect in porcine abdominal wall over a 6, 12, 26, or 52-week period. The study highlights the importance of aldosterone antagonism in preventing ischemia-reperfusion injury in both normal and diabetic hearts. The study aimed to investigate the effects of weight-bearing on the development of non-traumatic osteonecrosis in male Wistar rats. The rats were housed in controlled environments with unlimited food and water, and intravenous injections of 0.3 mg/kg lps and 20 mg/kg methylprednisolone were administered on days 1 and 2. The rats were then given methylprednisolone intramuscularly on days 3, 4, and 5. Histopathological examination of the femoral and humeral heads showed that histopathological osteonecrosis was observed in seven of 11 (63.6%) weight-bearing rats and six of 11 (54.5%) non-weight-bearing rats. The results of the study confirmed that weight-bearing does not contribute to the development of non-traumatic osteonecrosis in rats.

The study examined the perspectives of nurses and nonnurses at different system levels regarding nurses' involvement in national policy-making processes. The study aimed to examine the frequency of gram-negative bacteria (GNBs) causing neonatal urinary tract infections (UTIs) over an eight-year period in neonatal division of Bahrami Children's Hospital, Iran. The study found that e. coli was the most prevalent GNB causing UTIs in neonates, with a relative frequency of 64.4% (47 cases). Klebsiella and S. epidermidis were also found to be significantly resistant to ampicillin, with a relative frequency of 93.6% (44 cases). The study also found that the most sensitive GNBs toward neonatal empirical therapy antibiotics were cephalosporins (63.6%) and amikacin (100%). The study's findings suggest that neonatal UTIs are common and that empirical therapy regimens should be updated to better manage these infections.

The text discusses the findings of a study on congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), a group of inherited autosomal recessive disorders characterized by a deficiency in an adrenal enzyme leading to altered cortisol and aldosterone secretion. The study on trichomonas vaginalis infection in Peru provides insights into its prevalence, associated health outcomes, and the need for improved disease control programs. The text discusses Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome (LGS), a rare childhood epilepsy disorder characterized by tonic and atonic seizures, atonic seizures, and atypical absence seizures. LGS is classified as a symptomatic generalized epilepsy syndrome, with the second feature requiring an interictal awake electroencephalogram pattern consisting of slow spike wave discharges less than 3 Hz, usually with a generalized distribution. The third component of the definition of LGS is cognitive impairment involving moderate to severe mental retardation and behavioral disorders, including aggression and autistic features. The prognosis of LGS is poor, with a 20% risk of cognitive impairment and behavioral comorbidities. The text provides a detailed overview of the clinical features, treatment options, and potential benefits of rufinamide, a new anticonvulsant drug, for the treatment of LGS.

The study explored the role of chemical sexual signals in interpopulational recognition between five distinct populations of the Iberian wall lizard, P. hispanica, in central Spain. The text discusses the use of quantum dots (QDs) for nonamplified whole-mount in situ hybridization (WISH) in xenopus embryos. The provided text discusses the development and application of Cox proportional hazards regression models for predicting survival probabilities in pancreatic cancer patients. The models were developed using data from 18,352 pathologically confirmed cases of pancreatic cancer diagnosed between 2004 and 2009. The models were used to estimate survival probabilities and conditional survival probabilities for patients with localized and extended pancreatic cancer. The models were used to develop a real-time prognostic tool for predicting survival probabilities for patients with pancreatic cancer.

The text describes a method for measuring the frequency response of resonators using a downmixing technique. The device was electrostatically actuated and the driving voltage was applied to a side-gate parallel to the resonator. The drive signal was set to half the actuation frequency, and the amplitude of motion was proportional to the square of the actuation voltage. The bias voltage was used to downmix the resistance change at the actuation frequency. Typical measurement values were 1.5 V for the bias voltage at a measurement frequency of 500 kHz. All measurements were performed in a vacuum chamber at a pressure of 10 mbar and at room temperature. Thermomechanical noise was measured using the same set-up, with the drive electrode disconnected. Measurements were taken with a lock-in amplifier, which also generated the drive and bias signals. The Allan deviation was measured in open-loop configuration and extracted from the response of the resonator actuated at resonance frequency with a fixed driving frequency. The phase of the measured signal was monitored for a certain amount of time and transformed into frequency fluctuations using the phase response of the resonator. The Allan deviation was defined as the correlation coefficient of the filtered frequency traces f1 and f2, each of length n, where f1 and f2 are the sample means of f1 and f2, respectively, and sf1 and sf2 are their standard deviations.
